stage.#text: Scene--: a Street before the houses of PERIPLECOMENUS, and PYRGOPOLINICES, which adjoin each other.

p.#text: PLIEUSICLES, a young Athenian, is in love with Philocomasium, a Courtesan of Athens, who returns his affection. Being sent on public business to , a certain Captain of , Pyrgopolinices by name, comes to , and insinuates himself into the good graces of her mother, in order that he may get Philocomasium into his power. Having deceived the mother, he places the daughter on board ship and carries her off to . On this, Palaestrio, a faithful servant of Pleusicles, hastens to embark for , with the view of telling his master what has happened. The ship being taken by pirates, he is made captive, and by chance is presented as a gift to Pyrgopolinices. He recognises the mistress of Pleusicles in the Captain's house; but he carefully conceals from the Captain who he himself is. He then privately writes to Pleusicles, requesting him to come to . On arriving, Pleusicles is hospitably entertained by Periplecomenus, a friend of his father, an old gentleman who lives next door to the Captain. As Philocomasium has a private room of her own in the Captain's house, a hole is made through the partition wall, and by this contrivance she meets Pleusicles in the house of his entertainer, who gives his sanction to the plan.

At this juncture, the play begins. A servant of the Captain, named Sceledrus, has been appointed to be the keeper of Philocomnasium. Pursuing a monkey along the roof of the house, he looks down the skylight of the house next door, and there sees Pleusicles and Philocomasium conversing and toying with each other. When this has been discovered to be the case, a plan is arranged, by which Sceledrus shall not only not divulge to the Captain what he has seen, but shall even be made to believe that he has not actually seen it himself. Palaestrio, therefore, persuades him that the twin-sister of Philocomasium has arrived at , and with her lover is staying at their neighbour's house. To forward their designs, Palaestrio then invents another plan. He persuades the Captain to believe that the wife of his neighbour, Periplecomenus, is in love with him. Through his agency, a Courtesan, named Acroteleutium, pretends that she is the wife so desperately in love with the Captain. he believes this story, and, that he may the more conveniently receive her in his house, by the advice of Palaestrio, he sends Philocomasium away, and gives her into the charge of Pleusicles, who is disguised in the dress of a master of a ship. They go to the harbour and set sail, accompanied by Palaestrio, whom the Captain has given to Philocomasium at her request. The Captain, then, at the invitation of the maid of Acroteleutium, goes to the house next door, to visit her mistress. On this, Periplecomenus, with his servants, sallies forth upon him, and, having first threatened to cut him in pieces, and then having beaten and stripped him, they let him go, after they have exacted from him a confession that he has been rightly served, and a promise that he will molest no one in return for the treatment he has received.

note.#text: :  The literal meaning of the name of the swaggering Captain is "the much-conquering tower," or something similar. "Artotrogus" means "bread-eater." The word "Parasite" properly denotes "one person who dines with another." The name was originally given to persons who were assistants to the priests and high magistrates, and, consequently, had a respectable signification. The hangers-on, who are called "Parasites" by the Comic writers of  and , first received that name from Alexis, the Greek Comedian. It has been well remarked, that their chief characteristics were "importunity, love of sensual pleasures," and "the desire of getting a good dinner without paying for it." They may be subdivided into the jesting, the officious, and the flattering Parasite (), of which latter kind Artotrogus is an admirable specimen.  From ancient writers we find that it was their method to frequent the Courts of justice, market-places, baths, places for exercise, and other objects of public resort, with the view of obtaining a dinner, at the price of being the butt of their entertainer, and cheerfully submitting to the greatest humiliations.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Take ye care that the lustre of my shield is more bright than the rays of the sun are wont to be at the time when the sky is clear; that when occasion comes, the battle being joined, 'mid the fierce ranks right opposite it may dazzle the eyesight of the enemy. But, I wish to console this sabre of mine, that it may not lament nor be downcast in spirits, because I have thus long been wearing it keeping holiday, which so longs right dreadfully to make havoc of the enemy. But where is Artotrogus?

sp.speaker: ARTOTROGUS
sp.p: Here he is; he stands close by the hero, valiant and successful, and of princely form. Mars could not dare to style himself a warrior so great, nor compare his prowess with yours.

note.#text: :  These three crackjaw names are coined by Plautus much in the style of the names of the characters in Bombastes Furioso. They are mere gibberish, though the two latter are derived from Greek or Latin words; the first of which signifies "a son of a fighter at the sound of the trumpet."

p.#text: Him you mean whom I spared on the Gorgonidonian plains, where Bumbomachides Clytomestoridysarchides, the grandson of Neptune, was the chief commander?

sp.speaker: ARTOTROGUS
sp.p: I remember him; him, I suppose, you mean with the golden armour, whose legions you puffed away with your breath just as the wind blows away leaves or the reed-thatched roof.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: That, on my troth, was really nothing at all.

foreign.#text: Unum epityrum apud illum estur insane bene

: -- "" was the name of a dish much used by the people of Sicily, who ate it together with cheese. We learn from Cato (on Rural Matters), that it was made of various kinds of olives minced up, and mixed with oil, vinegar coriander, cummin, fennel, rue, and mint, and then preserved in jars.

p.#text: Faith, that really was nothing at all in comparison with other things I could mention-- which you never did. If any person ever beheld a more perjured fellow than this, or one more full of vain boasting, faith let him have me for himself, I'll resign myself for his slave; if 'tis not the fact that my one mess of olive pottage is eaten up by me right ravenously.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Where are you?

note.#text: :   is supposed by some to mean "the trunk" of the elephant; but it seems more probable that it here means "the fore-leg."

p.#text: Lo! here am I. I' troth in what a fashion it was you broke the fore-leg of even an elephant, in , with your fist.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: How?--the fore-leg?

sp.speaker: ARTOTROGUS
sp.p: I meant to say this--the thigh.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I struck the blow without an effort.

sp.speaker: ARTOTROGUS
sp.p: Troth, if, indeed, you had put forth your strength, your arm would have passed right through the hide, the entrails, and the frontispiece of the elephant.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I don't care for these things just now.

note.#text: :  He now addresses the Spectators, and honestly confesses why he is a Parasite.
:   is that which we call "teething." He says that he acts the flatterer that his teeth may not have time to grow through want of employment.

p.#text: I' faith, 'tis really not worth the while for you to tell me of it, who know right well your prowess.  'Tis my appetite creates all these plagues. I must hear him right out with my ears, that my teeth mayn't have time to grow, and whatever lie he shall tell, to it I must agree.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What was it I was saying?

sp.speaker: ARTOTROGUS
sp.p: O, I know what you were going to say just now. I' faith 'twas bravely done; I remember its being done.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What was that?

sp.speaker: ARTOTROGUS
sp.p: Whatever it was you were going to say.

note.#text: :  The "," or "," used by the ancients for the purpose of writing, were pieces of wood, mostly of an oblong shape, covered with wax, on which an impression was made with the "," or iron pen. They were sometimes made of ivory, but more frequently of citron-wood, beech, or fir The inside only of the tablet was covered with wax, the outer consisting of wood. The leaves were fastened at the back with wires, and opened and shut like the books of the present day. There was a raised margin to each leaf of the tablet, for the purpose of preventing the wax of the one from rubbing against the other. From two to five, six, or even more of these leaves were joined together, which were accordingly called "diptycha," "triptycha," and so on. Those tablets which contained legal documents were pierced through the outer edges with holes, through which a triple thread or string was passed, on which a seal was placed, in order to prevent forgery and to show that the deed was duly executed.

p.#text: Have you got your tablets?

note.#text: :  . Soldiers, when enlisted, were asked () whether they would take the oath. Hence the word "" means something tantamount to our word "enlist," or "recruit." The Parasite asks him if he is going to enlist, as the tablets would be wanted in the "Forum," or "Court of justice," for the purpose of taking down the oaths, and entering the names as the parties were sworn.

p.#text: Are you intending to enlist? I have them, and a pen as well.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: How cleverly you do suit your mind to my own mind.

note.#text: :  "." Literally, "should fly to me beforehand."

p.#text: 'Tis fit that I should know your inclinations studiously, so that whatever you wish should first occur to me.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What do you remember?

note.#text: :  This word is mere gibberish: it is compounded of Greek words, which would make it to mean "the place of hidden secrecy." The part of the flatterer seems to be a little overdone here.

p.#text: I do remember this. In  there were a hundred and fifty men, a hundred in Cryphiolathronia, thirty at , sixty men of Macedon, whom you slaughtered altogether in one day.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What is the sum total of those men?

sp.speaker: ARTOTROGUS
sp.p: Seven thousand.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: It must be as much: you keep the reckoning well.

sp.speaker: ARTOTROGUS
sp.p: Yet I have none of them written down; still, so I remember it was.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: By my troth, you have a right good memory.

note.#text: :  "." "" properly means "a lump of flesh," from which it came to signify "victuals" in general.

p.#text: . 'Tis the flesh-pots give it a fillip.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: So long as you shall do such as you have done hitherto, you shall always have something to eat: I will always make you a partaker at my table.

p.#text: Besides, in , you would have killed five hundred men altogether at one blow, had not your sabre been blunt.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I let them live, because I was quite sick of fighting.

p.#text: Why should I tell you what all mortals know, that you, Pyrgopolinices, live alone upon the earth, with valour, beauty, and achievements most unsurpassed? All the women are in love with you, and that not without reason, since you are so handsome. Witness those girls that pulled me by my mantle yesterday.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What was it they said to you?

sp.speaker: ARTOTROGUS
sp.p: They questioned me about you. "Is Achilles here?" says one to me. "No," says I, "his brother is." Then says the other to me: "By my troth, but he is a handsome and a noble man. See how his long hair becomes him Certainly the women are lucky who share his favours."

sp.speaker: PYBG.
sp.p: And pray, did they really say so?

note.#text: :  "." Strictly speaking, this word means the escort of a procession, whence it came to signify the procession itself.

p.#text: They both entreated me to bring you past to-day by way of a sight to them.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: 'Tis really a very great plague to be too handsome a man.

sp.speaker: ARTOTROGUS
sp.p: They are quite a nuisance to me; they are praying, entreating, beseeching me, to let them see you; bidding me be fetched to them; so that I can't give my attention to your business.

p.#text: It seems that it is time for us to go to the Forum, that I may count out their pay to those soldiers whom I have enlisted of late. For King Seleucus entreated me with most earnest suit that I would raise and enlist recruits for him. To that business have I resolved to devote my attention this day.

sp.speaker: ARTOTROGUS
sp.p: Come, let's be going then.

Its purpose is to acquaint us with the character of the Captain, who is to be duped and punished in the piece according to his desert.

:  The street doors of the ancients consisted of folding-doors, whence the plural form, "." These opened outward into the street, and not, like those of modern times, within. For this reason, when any person was coming out, it was customary for him to give warning by making a noise with his knuckles or a stick on the inside.

p.#text: To tell the subject of this our play, I have all willingness, if you will but have the kindness to listen to it. But he who does not wish to listen, let him arise and go out, that there may be room where he may sit who does wish to listen. Now I will disclose to you both the subject and the name of the play which we are just now about to act, and for the sake of which you are now seated in this mirthful place, "Alazon" is the name, in Greek, of this Comedy; the same we call in Latin. "the Braggart" (Gloriosus). This city is ; then, the Captain, my master, who has gone off hence to the Forum, a bragging, impudent, stinking fellow, brimful of lying and lasciviousness, says that all the women are following him of their own accord. Wherever he goes, he is the laughing.stock of all; and so, the Courtesans here--since they make wry mouths at him, you may see the greater part of them with lips all awry. I wish you now to know this, how I came to be his slave, from him to whom I was servant before; for 'tis not long that I lave been in slavery to him. Give your attention, for now I will begin the argument. A very worthy young man at  was my master. He was in love with a Courtesan, brought up at , in , and she on the other hand loved him; such affection is most worthy to be cherished. In the public service, he was sent to  as Ambassador on behalf of that mighty republic. In the mean time, by chance, this Captain came to . He introduced himself to this lady of my master, began to cajole her mother with presents of wine, trinkets, and costly treats; and so the Captain made himself on intimate terms with the procuress. As soon as ever an opportunity was presented for this Captain, he tricked this procuress, the mother of the damsel, whom my master loved. For, unknown to her mother, he put the daughter on board ship, and carried this woman, against her will, hither to . Soon as I knew that the lady of my master was carried off from , as quickly as ever I was able, I procured for myself a ship: I embarked, that I might carry tidings of this matter to my master at Naupactum. When we had got out to sea, some pirates, as they had hoped to do, took that ship on board of which I was; thus I was undone before I reached my master, for whom I had commenced to proceed on my voyage.  He that took me, gave me as a present to this same Captain. After he had taken me home to his own house, I saw there that favorite of my master who lived at . When, on the other hand, she perceived me, she gave me a sign with her eyes not to address her by name. Afterwards, when there was an opportunity, the damsel complained to me of her hard fate. She said that she wished to escape to  from this house, that she was attached to him, that master of mine who lived at , and that she had never hated any one more thoroughly than this same Captain. As I discovered the feelings of the damsel, I took tablets, sealed them in private, and gave them to a certain merchant to carry to him (my master, I mean, who was at , and who had so loved her), in order that he might come hither. He did not slight the message, for he both is come, and is lodging here next door, with his host, a friend of his father's, a nice old man. He, too, gives every assistance to his guest in his amour, and encourages and seconds us with his help and his advice. Therefore, here , in-doors, I have found a grand contrivance, by which to cause these lovers, each, to meet the other. For one room, which the Captain gave to his mistress for no one but herself to set foot in, in that same room I have dug a hole through the party-wall, in order that there may secretly be an ingress for the damsel from the one house to the other. And this I have done with the knowledge of the old gentleman; 'twas he that gave the advice. But my fellow-servant, whom the Captain has given as a keeper to his mistress, is a person of no great worth. By clever contrivances and ingenious devices, we will throw dust in his eyes, and we will make him so as not to see what he really does see. And that you may not hereafter make mistakes, this damsel to-day, in this house and in that, will perform in turn a double part, and will be the same, but will pretend to be another, person. Thus will the keeper of the damsel be gulled. But there is a noise at the door here of the old gentleman, our neighbour. 'Tis himself coming out 'tis he, the nice old man that I was speaking of.

note.#text: :  The "," or middle hall, of the houses of the Romans was a large apartment, roofed over, with the exception of an opening in the centre, which was called "," or "," towards which the roof sloped, so as to throw the rain-water down through pipes into a cistern below. Vitruvius says that the "" was from a fourth to a third of the size of the "," or hall below. It was probably glazed, and thus would form a sort of sloping skylight. In the present instance, it would seem to have overlooked the upper chamber, into which Philocomasium passed through the wall of the next house, to meet Pleusicles.

:  Commentators are much divided as to what is the meaning here of "," or, as some editions have it "." Some suppose that it simply means "the rules of the game with the ',' or 'dice;'" while others think that Plautus alludes to some recent enactment at  against games of chance. Such laws were repeatedly promulgated, but immediately became a mere dead letter. "" means either a person's "anklebone," or the "knuckle-bone" of an animal, which latter was marked with numbers on four sides, and used by the Greeks and Romans in sets of four for the purpose of dice. The old man puns on the two meanings, and says, "I'll take care that your '' (or ankle-bones) are broken, so that" (if we adopt the first meaning) "you shall not cheat at dice in future," or (if we take the second interpretation) "you shall not have an opportunity of infringing the public laws." "," which is translated "monkey," is. strictly speaking, "a she-ape;" probably a present from the Captain to Philocomasium.

p.#text: . Faith, if you don't in future smash his ankle-bones for any stranger that you see on my tiles, I will cut you so with lashes as to make thongs of your sides. My neighbours, i' faith, are overlookers of what is going on in my own house; so often are they peeping down through the skylight. And now, therefore, I give you all notice, whatever person of this Captain's household you shall see upon our tiles, except Palaestrio only, push him headlong here into the street. Suppose he says that he is following some hen, or pigeon, or monkey; woe be to you, if you don't badly maul the fellow even to death. And so, that they may commit no infringement against the laws of dice, do you take good care that they keep holiday at home without any ankle-bones at all.

. Something amiss,--what, I know not, has been done him by our family so far as I can hear, inasmuch as the old man has ordered the ankles of my fellow-servants to be broken. But he has excepted me; nothing care I what he does to the rest of them. I'll accost the old man.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: The person that is coming this way, is he coming towards me? He comes as if he was coming to me.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: How do you do, Periplecomenus?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: There are not many men, if I were to wish, whom I would rather now see and meet with than yourself.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What's the matter? What disturbance have you with our family?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: We are done for.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: The thing's discovered.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What thing's discovered?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Some one just now of your household was looking in from the tiles through our skylight at Philocomasium and my guest as they were toying together.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What person saw it?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Your fellow-servant.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Which person was it?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: I don't know; he took himself off so suddenly--in an instant.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I suspect I'm ruined.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: When he went away, I cried: "Hallo! you sir!" said I, "what are you doing upon the tiles?" As he went away he replied to me in these terms, that he was following a stray'd monkey.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Woe to wretched me! that I must be ruined for a worthless beast. But is Philocomasium there with you even still?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: When I came out, she was there.

note.#text: :  He seems to use the word "," "comrades," or "fellow-slaves," as applying to the relation between Philocomasium and the other slaves in the house; since, falling into the hands of the Captain, she had become reduced to the condition of a slave. The cross was the instrument of a punishment among the Romans, which was especially inflicted upon slaves. It was usually in shape like the letter T or X, but there were various other forms of it. The condemned carried his own cross, and, being first stripped, was either nailed or bound to it, and in the latter ase was generally left to die of hunger. It must be remembered that in the time of the Roman Republic the laws did not protect the person or life of the slaves, who were sometimes very barbarously treated.

p.#text: If she is, then bid her return to our house as soon as ever she can, that the servants may see that she is at home; unless, indeed, she wishes that we, who are slaves, her fellow- slaves, should all be given up together to tortures by the cross on account of her courting.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: I bade her do so; unless you would aught else.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I would. Tell her this: that, by my troth, she must not hesitate at all to bring in play her skill and cleverness.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: In what way?

note.#text: :  He uses a rather out-of-the-way simile here; he means to say, "a woman never needs to go to a gardener's, who has a garden of her own, with a most plentiful stock of artfulness," &c. Some Commentators fancy that he means literally to say that women have always at hand plenty of poisonous plants for the purposes of mischief, and that they need not the assistance of the gardener or nurseryman when they wish to carry out their designs. Such an interpretation seems, however, to be very far-fetched.
:  "," literally," "face; similar to a common expression it use with us.

p.#text: That by her words she may persuade him who saw her here at your house, that he did not see her. Should he accuse her, on the other hand let her convince him with her oath. Even though she were seen a hundred times over, still let her deny it.  For, if she is at all inclined to ill, a woman never goes begging to the gardener for material, she has a garden at home and a stock of her own for all mischievous contrivances; at home she has impudence, a lying tongue, perfidiousness, malice, and boldness, self-conceit, assurance, and deceitfulness,--at home she has wiles,--at home captivating contrivances,--stratagems at home.
I'll tell her this, if she shall be in-doors here . But what is it, Palaestrio, that you are considering with yourself in your mind?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Be silent a moment, while I am calling a council in my mind, and while I am considering what I am to do, what plan I must contrive, on the other hand, as a match for my crafty fellow-servant, who has seen her billing here in your house; so that what was seen may not have been seen.

note.#text: :  "" strictly means, "to have a tremulous motion imparted." "" properly meant "to play at a game called ','" in which two persons suddenly raised or compressed the fingers, and at the same moment each guessed the number of the other. The expression also means, "to determine anything by suddenly raising the fingers," as who is to do or to have anything.
:  He means that Palaestrio looks up in thought, while his clenched hand is placed, as though it were a pillar beneath his chin.

:  "." The speaker being supposed to be a Greek, and a native of , he would speak of a Roman as being "." It is generally supposed that Plautus here refers to the Roman poet Naevius, who had a habit of using this posture, and was, as is thought, at that moment in prison for having offended, in one of his Comedies, the family of the Metelli. He was afterwards liberated on having apologised in his plays called  (the Wizard) and  (the Lion). Periplecomenus thinks that this posture bodes no good, and is ominous of an evil result.
:  He says that the actor is well representing the character of the slave. The actors themselves, as already remarked, were generally slaves in the earlier times of the Republic.

p.#text: Do contrive one; in the meantime, I'll retire hence to a distance from you, to this spot.  Look at him, please , revolving his cares with brow severe, how he stands. He strikes his breast with his fingers I fancy he's about to call his heart outside. See, he shifts his posture; again he places his left hand upon his left thigh. His right hand is reckoning down his plans upon his fingers; in despair he strikes his thigh. His right hand is moving rapidly; with difficulty does it suggest what he is to do. He snapshis fingers now; he's striving hard; full oft he changes his position. But see how he shakes his head; it pleases him not what he has hit upon. Whatever it is, nothing crude will he bring forth, something well-digested will he produce. But see, he is building; he has placed his hand as a pillar beneath his chin. Have done with it in truth, this mode of building pleases me not; for I have heard say that the head of a foreign Poet is wont to be supported thus, over whom two guards are ever at all hours keeping watch. Bravo! how becomingly he stands,--i' faith, how like a very slave, and how faithful to his part. Never, this day,will he rest, before he has completed that which he is in search of. He has it, I suspect. Come--to the business you're about: keep wide awake, think not of sleep; unless, indeed, you wish to be keeping your watch here all checquered o'er with stripes. 'Tis T, that am talking to you; schemer, don't you know that I am speaking to you? Palaestrio! awake, say; arouse yourself, I say; 'tis daylight now, I say.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I hear you.

p.#text: Don't you see that the enemy is upon you, and that siege is being laid to your back? Take counsel, then; obtain aid and assistance in this matter; the hastily, not the leisurely, is befitting here. Get the start of them in some way, and in some direction this moment lead around your troops. Close round the enemy in siege; prepare the convoy for our side. Cut off the enemy's provision, secure yourself a passage, by which supplies and provision may be enabled in safety to reach yourself and your forces. Look to this business; the emergency is sudden. Invent--contrive--this instant give us some clever plan; so that that which has been seen here within, may not have been seen; that which has been done, may not have been done. There, my man, you undertake a great enterprise; lofty the defences which you erect. If you yourself alone but say you undertake this, I have a certainty that we are able to rout our foes.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I do say so, and I do undertake it.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: And I do pronounce that you shall obtain that which you desire.

p.#text: May  kindly bless you then!

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: But, friend, do you impart to me the plan which you have devised.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Be silent, then, while I am inducting you in the direction of my devices; that you may know as well as my own self my plans.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: The same you shall receive safe from the same spot where you have deposited them.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: My master is surrounded with the hide of an elephant, not his own, and has no more wisdom than a stone.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: I myself know the same thing.

p.#text: Now, thus I would begin upon my plan; this contrivance I shall act upon. I shall say that her other own twin-sister has come here from , with a certain person, her lover, to Philocomasium, as like to her as milk is to milk. I shall say that they are lodged and entertained here in your house.
Bravo! bravo! cleverly thought of. I approve or your device.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: So that, if my fellow-servant should accuse her before the Captain, and say that he has seen her here at your house, toying with another man, I shall assert, on the other hand, that my fellow-servant has seen the other one, the sister, at your house, fondling and toying with her own lover.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Aye, most excellent. I'll say the same, if the Captain shall inquire of me.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: But do you say that they are extremely alike; and this must be imparted in time to Philocomasium, in order that she may know; that she mayn't be tripping if the Captain should question her.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: A very clever contrivance. But if the Captain should wish to see them both in company together, what shall we do then?

note.#text: :  Among the Romans some began the day with the "," which, however, was in general confined to sick persons, the very luxurious, or the labouring classes. From Martial we learn that it was taken about four in the morning, and it can, therefore, hardly have corresponded with our breakfast. Bread, with cheese or dried fruit, was used at this meal. The "," which is here translated "breakfast," is supposed to have been a hasty meal, and to have been taken from twelve to one o'clock in the day. Sometimes it was of simple character, while occasionally fish, fruit, and wine formed part of the repast, in which latter case it would almost correspond with the luncheon of modern times.

:  It was the custom of the Romans, after the second course of the "" or "dinner" was taken away, to have wine on the table, and to prolong the evening with conversation; perhaps this period is here referred to as furnishing one of the excuses to be made.
:  "" usually signifies "she is not at leisure," i.e., "she is busy;" but here it is thought to mean the reverse, "she is not at work," "she is taking her ease," and consequently cannot be disturbed.

p.#text: That's easy enough. Three hundred excuses may be picked up--she is not at home; she has gone out walking; she is asleep; she is dressing; she is bathing; she is at breakfast; she is taking dessert; she is engaged; she is enjoying her rest; in fact, she can't come. There are as many of these put-offs as you like, if I can only persuade him at the very outset to believe that to be true which shall be contrived.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: I like what you say.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Go in-doors then; and if the damsel's there, bid her return home directly, and instruct and tutor her thoroughly in this plan, that she may understand our scheme, as we have begun it, about the twin-sister.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: I'll have her right cleverly tutor'd for you. Is there anything else?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Only, be off in-doors.

p.#text: I'm off.

note.#text: :  "" was a contrivance used in warfare, made of timber covered with raw hides to prevent its being burnt, under which the assailants were sheltered in their attempts to scale the walls of a fortification. It probably answered very nearly to what is called a "mantelet," in the language of fortification. "" was a similar engine, in the form of a turret, and moving on wheels.

p.#text: And I'll go home, too; and I'll conceal the fact that I am giving her my aid in seeking out the man, which fellow-servant of mine it was, that to-day was following the monkey. For it cannot be but in his conversation he must have made some one of the household acquainted about the lady of his master, how that he himself has seen her next door here toying with some stranger spark. I know the habit myself; "I can't hold my tongue on that which I know alone." If I find out the person who saw it, I'll plant against him all> my mantelets and covered works. The material is prepared; 'tis a sure matter that I must take this person by force, and by thus besieging him. If so I don't find the man, just like a hound I'll go smelling about, even until I shall have traced out the fox by his track. But our door makes a noise: I'll lower my voice; for here is the keeper of Philocomasium, my fellow-servant, coming out of doors.

div2.stage: Enter SCLEDRUS from the CAPTAIN's house.

note.#text: :  "." Literally, "is seeking a bad job for herself."

p.#text: Unless, in fact, I have been walking this day in my sleep upon the tiles, i' faith, I know for sure that I have seen here, at our neighbour's next door, Philocomasium, the lady of my master, on the high road to mischief to herself.
. 'Twas he that saw her billing, so far as I have heard him say.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Your fellow-servant. How are you, Sceledrus?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I am glad that I have met you, Palaestrio.

sp.speaker: PAT.
sp.p: What now? Or what's the matter? Let me know.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I'm afraid.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What are you afraid of?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: By my troth, lest, this day, as many domestics as there are of us here, we shall jump into a most woful punishmient by way of torture.

note.#text: :  Some critics think that there is some hidden meaning or allusion in the words "" and "." That hardly seems to be the case, for Palaestrio might naturally say in return to the warning of the other, "I like neither your jumping in nor our jumping out."

p.#text: Jump you alone, please; for I don't at all like this jumping in and jumping out.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Perhaps you don't know what new mischance has happened at home?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What mischance is this?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: A disgraceful one.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Do you then keep it to yourself alone: don't tell it me; I don't want to know it.

p.#text: But I won't let you not know it. To-day I was following our monkey upon the tiles, next door there.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: By my troth, Sceledrus, a worthless fellow, you were following a worthless beast.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: The Gods confound you!

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: That befits yourself, since you began the conversation.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: By chance, as it happened, I looked down there through the skylight, into the next house; and there I saw Philocomasium toying with some strange young man, I know not whom.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What scandalous thing is this I hear of you, Sceledrus?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I' faith, I did see her, beyond a doubt.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What, yourself?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Yes, I myself, with these eyes of mine.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Get away, it isn't likely what you say, nor did you see her.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Do I, then, appear to you as if I were purblind?

note.#text: :  "." This metaphor is borrowed from the custom among the Romans of laying the new-born child upon the ground upon which it was taken up () by the father, or other person who intended to stand in the place of parent to it.

p.#text: 'Twere better for you to ask the doctor about that. But, indeed, if the Gods only love you, don't you rashly father this idle story. Now are you breeding thence a fatal dilemma for your legs and head; for, in two ways, the cause is contrived for you to be ruined, unless you put a check upon your foolish chattering.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: But how, two ways?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I'll tell you. First then, if you falsely accuse Philocomasium, by that you are undone; in the next place, if it is true, having been appointed her keeper, there you are undone.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: What may happen to me, I know not; I know for certain that I did see this.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Do you persist in it, unfortunate wretch?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: What would you have me say to you, but that I did see her? Moreover, she is in there, next door, at this very moment.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What! Isn't she at home?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Go and see. Go in-doors yourself; for I don't ask now for any confidence to be put in me.

p.#text: I'm determined to do so.

stage: PALAESTRIO goes into the CAPTAIN'S house.
p.#text: I'll wait here for you.

note.#text: :  "." Literally. "cross"

p.stage: Enter PALAESTRIO from the CAPTAIN's house.
p.#text: In this direction will I be on the watch for her, how soon the heifer may betake herself from the pasture this way towards her stall. What now shall I do? The Captain gave me to her as her keeper. Now, if I make a discovery, I'm undone; if I am silent, still I am undone, if this should be discovered. What is there more abandoned or more daring than a woman? While I was upon the tiles, this woman betook herself out of doors from her dwelling. By my troth, 'twas a brazen act she did. If, now, the Captain were to know of this, i' faith, I believe he would pull down the whole entire house next door, and me he would send to the gibbet.. Whatever comes of it, i' faith, I'll hold my tongue rather than come to a bad end. I cannot keep effectual guard on a woman that puts herself up for sale.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Sceledrus, Sceledrus, what one man is there on earth more impudent than yourself? Who more than yourself has been born with the Deities hostile and enraged?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Do you want those eyes of yours gouged out, with which you see what never existed?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: How, what never existed?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I would not buy your life at the price of a rotten nut.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What's the matter, do you ask?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: And why shouldn't I ask?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Why don't you beg for that tongue of yours to be cut out, that prates so at random?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Why should I beg for that?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Why, Philocomasium is there at home, she whom you were saying that you had seen next door kissing and toying with another man.

note.#text: :  He means to say that his sight must have failed him, and, by way of accounting for it, that he must have lived on bread made of darnel. This grain was supposed not only to cause the person eating to appear as it intoxicated, but very seriously to affect the eyesight. Ovid says in the , "Let the fields, also, be clear of darnel that weakens the eyes."

p.#text: 'Tis a wonder that you are in the habit of feeding on darnel, with wheat at so low a price.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Because you are so dim of sight.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: You gallows-bird, 'tis you, indeed, that are blind, with a vengeance, and not dim of sight; for, sure enough, there she is at home.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: How? At home?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: At home, i' faith, undoubtedly.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Be off with you; you are playing with me, Palaestrio

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: My hands are dirty, then.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Because I am playing with dirt.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: A mischief on your head.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p:
Nay rather, Sceledrus, it shall be on yours, I promise you, unless you
change for fresh your eyes and your talk.  But our door made a noise.

p.#text: Well, I shall watch here out of doors, for there is no way by which she can pass hence in-doors, except through the front door.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: But there she is, at home.  I don't know, Scledrus, what mischief is possessing you.

p.stage: Points to the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.
p.#text: I see for my own self, I judge for my own self, I have especial faith in my own self:  no man shall frighten me out of it, but that she is in that house.    Here I'll take my stand, that she may not steal out home without my knowledge.
This fellow is in my hands;  now will I drive him from his strong hold.   Do you wish me now to make you own that you don't see correctly?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Come, do it then.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: And that you neither think aright in your mind, nor yet make use of your eyes?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I'd have you do it.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Do you say, then that the lady of your master is there in that house?

p.#text: I assert, as well, that I saw here here in this house , toying with a strange man.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Don't you know that there is no communication between our house here and that one?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I know it.

note.#text: :  "" was either a balcony or terrace before a house, or on the top of it, which was exposed to the sun.  People walked there in the cool of the evening.  It was from a  that David first saw Bathsheba.

p.#text: Neither by the terrace, nor by the garden, only through the skylight?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I know it.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What then, if she is now at home?  If I shall make her, so as you may see her,come out hence from our house, are you not deserving of many a lashing?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I am so deserving.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Watch that door, then, that she may not privily betake herself out thence without your knowledge and pass here into our house.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: 'Tis my intention to do so.

note.#text: :    Lindemann thinks that  here means "upon her feet," as much as to say "I'll bring her to you on her feet and not standing on her head.  The true meaning of the passage seems to be, "I'll bring her to you standing upon , and not flying with wings as you seem to expect.

p.#text: Upon her feet will I place her this moment here before you in the street.

stage: PALAESTRIO goes into the CAPTAIN's house.
p.#text: Come, then, and do so.

note.#text: :    The , or food of the slaves, usually consisted of salt, fish, oil, vinegar, and the olives that were windfalls.  This food received its name from being eaten with a kind of porridge made from meal or pulse, which was generally eaten before bread was used, and probably continued to be the food of the slaves.

p.#text: I wish to know whether I did see that which I did see, or whether he can do that which he says he can do  make her to be at home.  For, really, I have eyes of my own, and I don't ever ask to borrow them out of doors.  But this fellow is forever fawning about her;  he is always near her;  he is called first to meat;  his mess is given to him first.  For this fellow has been, perhaps, about three years with us;  nor fares it better with any other servant in our family than with him.  But it is necessary for me to mind what I am about;  to keep my eye upon this door.  If I take my station here, this way, in faith, I warrant they will never impose on me.

div2.stage: Enter PALAESTRIO and PHILOCOMASIUM from the CAPTAIN's house.

p.stage: (speaking to her in a low voice as he enters)
p.#text: Be sure to remember my instructions.
It's strange you should so often remind me.
But I fear you may not prove cunning enough.

Give me even ten scholars, though far from artful, I could instruct them so as to prove artful;  in me alone is there a superabundance of artfulness;  come, then, now put your plans in force;  I'll step aside here.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What have you to say, Scledrus?

p.#text: I'm about this business of mine;  I have got ears, say what you please.

note.#text: :  Sceledrus is standing before the door with both arms stretched out that Philocomasium may not come out without his knowing. Palaestrio tells him, that when he comes to be fastened on the cross for his negligence, he will have to assume that attitude. The gate here alluded to is supposed to have been the , or Metian gate at , a place near which was devoted to the punishment of slaves.  and other Greek cities had 'the gate of Charon," through which malefactors passed to punishment.

p.#text: I think that in that self-same position you will have to die outside the gates, when, with hands outstretched, you will be carrying your cross.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: For what reason so?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Just look on your left hand; who is that lady?

p.#text: . O ye immortal Gods, it really is the lady of my master!

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I' faith, so she seems to me as well. Do then, now, since so you would have it----

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Do what?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Die this very instant.

p.#text: . Where is this faithful servant, who has falsely accused me in my innocence of this most heinous crime?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: See, here he is; 'tis he that told it me,--assuredly 'twas he.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: Villain, did you say that you had seen me next door here kissing?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Besides, he said it was with some strange young man.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I' faith, I did. say so, undoubtedly.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: You, saw me?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Yes, with these self-same eyes.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: I fancy you will lose those eyes, which see more than what they really do see.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: By my faith, I shall never be intimidated from having seen what I really did see.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: In my foolishness I am delaying too long in parleying with this madman, whom, by the powers, I'll punish with death.

note.#text: :  That is, "you cannot make me not to have seen what I really did see."

p.#text: Forbear to threaten me: I know that the cross will prove my tomb; there are laid my forefathers, my father, grandfather, great-grandfather, great-great-grandfather. 'Tis not in possibility, however, for these eyes of mine to be dug out by your threats. But I want a few words with you; prithee, Palaestrio, whence came she hither?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Whence but from our house?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: From our house?

note.#text: :  "? ()" Literally, "do you look at me?" The Romans, when they wished to impress any one with the belief that they were speaking seriously and in good faith, used this phrase, or "," "look at me now." Our expression, "do you look me in the face and say so?" is somewhat similar.

p.#text: Do you credit me?

note.#text: :  The "" were a kind of lattice or trellice-work, which, as well as network, was sometimes placed before windows to prevent serpents and other noxious reptiles from getting in.

p.#text: I do credit you: but 'tis a thing to be wondered at, how she has been able to return from that house to ours. For, beyond a doubt, we have neither a terrace to our house, nor any garden, nor any window but what is latticed.  But, undoubtedly, I did see you in the house next door.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Do you persist, you rascal, in pretending to accuse her?

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: In good sooth, then, the dream has not turned out untrue, that I dreamed last night.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What did you dream?

p.#text: I'll tell you; but, I pray you, give attention. Last night, in my sleep, my twin-sister seemed to have come from  to  with a certain person, her lover. Both of them seemed to me to be having their lodgings here next door.
. The dream that's being related is Palaestrio's--pray, go on.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: I seemed to be delighted because my sister had come, and on her account I seemed to be incurring a most grievous suspicion. For, in my sleep, my own servant seemed to accuse me, as you are now doing, of being caressed by a strange young man, whereas it was that own twin-sister of mine, who had been toying with her own friend. Thus did I dream that I was wrongfully accused of a crime.

note.#text: :  After any ill-omened dream, it was the custom to offer corn and frankincense to Jupiter Prodigialis, "the disposer of prodigies," and other of the Deities, in order that evil might be averted.

p.#text: And isn't just the same thing befalling you when awake, that you speak of as seen in your sleep? Capital; i' faith, the dream is verified: go in-doors, and pray. I should recommend that this be told to the Captain.
I am resolved to do so; nor, in fact, will I allow myself, with impunity, to be accused of disgraceful conduct.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I fear for the thing I have done; my back does so tingle all over.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Are you not aware that you are done for?

p.#text: Now, indeed, I'm sure she is at home; I am now resolved to watch our door, wheresoever she may be.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: But, prithee, Sceledrus, how very like the dream she dreamt to what has happened; and how you really did believe that you had seen her kissing. * * * * *

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: And do you suppose that I didn't see her?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I' faith, I verily believe you'll come to your senses when 'tis too late. If this matter should only reach our master, you certainly are undone.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Now, at length, I find out that there was a mist placed before my eyes.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I' faith, that really has been plain for some time now; as she was here in-doors all the while.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Not a word of certainty have I to utter; I did not see her, although I did see her.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: By my troth, through this folly of yours you certainly have nearly ruined us; while you have wished to prove yourself faithful to your master, you have been almost undone. But the door of our next neighbour makes a noise; I'll be silent.

note.#text: Sceledrus having been duly prepared, Philocomasium appears as her twin-sister, who is supposed to have come the day before from  to , and gives directions about returning thanks for having landed in safety. As the circumstance of the communication between the houses is known to the Audience, and is not suspected by Sceledrus, his embarrassment is highly diverting, and very cleverly depicted.

stage.#text: Enter PHILOCOMASIUM, dressed in another habit, from the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.

note.#text: :  In the language of the Poets, Neptune and the inferior Sea Divinities are supposed to have their temples and abodes in the sea and rivers.

p.#text: . Put fire on the altar, that in my joy I may return praises and thanks to Diana of , and that I may send up for her a grateful smoke with odours of : she who has preserved me in the realms of Neptune and amid the boisterous temples, where with raging billows I have been so recently dismayed.
. Palaestrio! O Palaestrio!

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Sceledrus! O Sceledrus! What is it you want?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: This lady that has come out of that house just now--is she Philocomasium, our master's lady, or is she not?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I' faith, I think, it seems to be she. But 'tis a wondrous thing how she could pass from our house to next door; if, indeed, it is she.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: And have you any doubt that this is she?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: It seems to be she.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Let us approach her, and accost her. Hallo! how's this, Philocomasium? What is there owing to you in that house? What is your business there? Why are you silent now? I am speaking to you.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: No, faith, you are talking to yourself; for nothing at all does she answer.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I am addressing you, woman, brimful of viciousness and disgrace, who are roaming about among your neighbours.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: To whom are you talking?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: To whom but to yourself?

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: What person are you? Or what business have you with me?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: O, you ask me who I am, do you?

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: Why shouldn't I ask that which I don't know?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Who am I, then, if you don't know him?

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: You are an annoyance to me, whoever you are, both you and he.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: What? don't you know us?

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: No, neither of you.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I very much fear----

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What do you fear?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Why, that we have lost ourselves somewhere or other; for she says that she knows neither you nor me.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I wish, Sceledrus, to examine into this, whether we are ourselves, or else some other persons; lest secretly somehow some one of our neighbours may have transformed us without our knowing it.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: For my part, beyond a doubt, I am my own self.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I' faith, and so am I.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: My lady, you are seeking your destruction. To you I am speaking; hark you, Philocomasium!

note.#text: :  "." The Commentators seem to think that this means no more than "by my wrong name." The word "" seems, however, to refer to the extreme length of the name, as well as the fact that it does not belong to her.

p.#text: What craziness possesses you, to be calling me wrongly by a crackjaw name?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: How now! What are you called, then?

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: My name is Glycera.

note.#text: In the original Latin, the name is , which sounds like the Greek word for "just" or "righteous."  Scledrus is making a pun.

p.#text: For a bad purpose, Philocomasium, you wish to have a wrong name. Away with you, shocking woman; for most notably are you doing a wrong to my master.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: I?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Yes, you.

p.#text: I, who arrived from  yesterday evening at , with my lover, a young man of ?
Tell me, what business have you here in ?
I had heard that my own twin-sister is here in ; I came here to look for her.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: You're a good-for-nothing woman.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: Yes, i' faith, I am a very foolish one to be parleying with you fellows. I am going.

p.#text: I won't let you go.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: Let me go.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: You are discovered in the fact. I won't let you go.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: But my hands shall just now sound again against your cheek, if you don't let me go.

p.#text: . Why the plague are you standing idle? Why don't you hold her on the other side?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I don't choose to bring the business down upon my back. How do I know but that this is not Philocomasium, but is some other female that resembles her?

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: Will you let me go, or will you not let me go?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: No; by force and against your will, in spite of you, I'll drag you home, unless you'll go of your own accord.

p.stage: pointing to the house of PERIPLECOMENUS

note.#text: :  "," "my lodging when abroad." "" originally meant merely "a foreigner;" whereas its later signification was "an enemy."

p.#text: . This is my lodging here abroad, at  is my home.
But your master lives here .

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: I have nothing to do with that house, nor do I know or understand yourselves what persons you are.

note.#text: :  "." "" was a technical expression, meaning "to bring an action," or "to sue a person at law." It is said to have been the formal expression in commencing an action or suit.

p.#text: Proceed against me at law. I'll never let you go, until you give me your solemn word that you will go indoors here  if I let go of you.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: You are compelling me by force, whoever you are. I give you my word, that if you let go of me, I will go into that house where you bid me.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Then, now I let go of you.

p.stage: Runs into the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.
p.#text: And, as I'm let go, I'll go in here.
She has acted with a woman's honour.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Sceledrus, you've lost the prey through your hands; as sure as possible she is the lady of our master. Do you intend to act in this matter with spirit?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: How am I to act?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Bring me a sword out here from in-doors.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: What will you do with it?

note.#text: :  The mock rage of Palaestrio here is admirably drawn

p.#text: I'll break right into the house; and whatever man I see in-doors there caressing Philocomasium, I'll behead him on the spot.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: And do you think that it was she?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I' faith, it was she, sure enough.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: But how she did dissemble.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Go, bring me a sword out here.

p.#text: I'll have it here this moment.

p.stage: Enter SCLEDRUS from the CAPTAIN's house.
p.#text: Beyond a doubt, neither any horse nor foot has so great a degree of boldness in carrying out anything with as much confidence as some women. How cleverly and how skilfully she performed her part in both her characters!--how her wary keeper, my fellow-servant, is being gulled! 'Tis most fortunate that the passage communicates through the party-wall.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Hallo! Palaestrio, there's no occasion for the sword.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: How so?--or what's the matter now?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Our master's lady is there, at home.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What? At home?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: She's lying on the sofa.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Faith, but you've certainly brought on yourself a disagreable affair, according to what you report.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Inasmuch as you have dared to touch that lady next door here.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I' faith, I fear it much. But no one shall ever make her to be any other than her own twin-sister.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: 'Twas she, in troth, that you saw toying: and, in fact, 'tis plain that it is she, as you remark.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: What was there more likely than that I should have been undone, if I had spoken of it to my master.

p.stage: Goes into the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.
p.#text: Then, if you're wise, you'll hold your tongue. It befits a servant to know of more than he speaks. I'm going to leave you, that I may not at all participate in your designs. And I shall go to our neighbour here; these turmoils of yours don't please me. My master, if he comes, should he inquire for me, I shall be there; send for me next door.

stage: Places himself against the CAPTAIN'S door.
p.#text: Well, he's off; nor cares he any more for his master's business than if he were not in his service. For sure she really is now here in-doors in the house, for I myself found her just now lying down in our house. I am resolved now to employ myself in watching.

Faith, but these men here, these servants of my neighbour the Captain, take me not to be a man, but a woman, so much do they trifle with me. My lady guest, who came here yesterday from  with the gentleman, my guest, is she to be mauled about and made fun of here in the street--a lady, free-born and free?
. By my troth, I'm undone. He's coming in a straight line up towards me. I fear that this matter may cause me great trouble, so far as I have heard this old gentleman speak.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: I'll up to this fellow. Was it you, Sceledrus, source of mischief, that were just now making fun of my lady guest before the house?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Good neighbour, listen, I beg.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: I, listen to you?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I wish to clear myself.

note.#text: :  He alludes to the lawless character of the mercenary soldier, whose name, "," came afterwards to be applied to robbers and cut-throats of all descriptions. It may be here remarked, that the word "," which is applied throughout the play to their master, the Captain, is a general term for one following the profession of arms, whether officer or private. The word is translated "Captain," without reference to his rank, any further than that he was a commanding officer.

p.#text: You, clear yourself to me, who have done an action so gross and so unbecoming? And because you are soldiers, do you suppose, you gallows-bird, that you may do what you like with us?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: May I----?

note.#text: :  The slaves were more frequently beaten with , or whips; but they were sometimes scourged with , or rods. This was done by the "," a slave who was kept for the purpose
:  ";" literally, "worthy," or deserving of yourself.

p.#text: But so may all the Gods and Goddesses prosper me, if a punishment with the rod is not given to you at my request, a long and lasting one, from morning to evening; because you have been breaking my gutters and my tiles, while you were following there a monkey like your own self; because, too, you have been peeping down from there at my guest in my house, when he was caressing and fondling his mistress; besides, you have dared to accuse the chaste lady of your master of criminality, and myself of a heinous offence; and further, because you have dared to maul about my lady guest before my house. If the punishment of the whip is not given to you, I will cause your master to be more laden with disgrace than the sea is full of waves in a heavy storm.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I am driven to such straits, Periplecomenus, that I don't know whether it is fitter for me rather to dispute this matter with you, or whether, if she is not our lady, and if our lady was not seen by me, it seems more proper for me to excuse myself to you; as even now I don't know which I saw, so like is that guest of yours to our lady--if, indeed, she is not the same person.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Go into my house and look: you'll soon see.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: May I go?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Why, I command you; go and examine at your leisure.

p.stage: Goes into the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.
p.#text: I am determined to do so.

stage: probably looking up to a window in the CAPTAIN'S house
Enter SCLEDRUS from the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.

note.#text: :  Directly Sceledrus turns his back, the old man calls out for Philocomasium, who is supposed at that moment to be in the Captain's house. How he does so is somewhat of a mystery to the Commentators. , in his translation, suggests that he calls through the window, where it is natural to imagine that Philocomasium might be stationed within hearing to observe all that passed. He could hardly, however, call "through" the window of the ground floor, as these were generally more than six feet from the ground; and, indeed, there were rarely any windows at all on the basement. It is most likely that Philocomasium is hidden behind the "" or "lattice" of the window in her room on the first-floor, whence she observes all that passes. In a future line we find Acroteleutium and Milphidippa owning that they had been watching from the window what was going on outside. Schmieder thinks that the whole plan having been prearranged between Periplecomenus and Philocomasium, he merely on this occasion makes a sign to her, the meaning of which is here expressed in words, and he supposes, what it does not deem necessary to suppose, that his servants have been ordered to delay Sceledrus, so as to give time to the damsel to pass through into his house.

p.#text: . Ho! Philocomasium! pass instantly, with all speed, into my house; 'tis absolutely necessary. Afterwards, when Sceledrus shall have come out from my house, pass quickly, with all haste, back again to your own house. By my troth, now, I'm afraid she'll be making some blunder. Should he not see the woman * * * * My door opens.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: O ye immortal Gods! A woman more like, and more the same, who is not the same, I do not think the Gods could make.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: What now?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I certainly merit chastisement.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: What then? Is it she?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Although 'tis she, 'tis not she.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Have you seen this lady?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I have seen both her and the gentleman, your guest, caressing and kissing.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Is it she?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Would you know for certain?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I should like to.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Go you this instant into your own house: see whether your lady is within.

p.#text: Very well: you've advised me rightly. I'll be out again to you this instant.

p.stage: Enter SCLEDRUS from the CAPTAIN's house.
p.#text: I' faith, I never saw any man more cleverly fooled, and by more singular devices. But here he is coming.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Periplecomenus, by Gods and men, and by my own folly, and by your knees! I do beseech you----

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: What now?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Pardon my ignorance and my folly; now, at length, I know that I am half-witted, blind, and thoughtless; for, behold! Philocomasium is at home.

note.#text: :  "." Literally, "bearer of the '.'" Slaves are repeatedly thus called in these plays, as, by way of punishment for their misdeeds, they were compelled to carry a "," or two pieces of wood shaped like the letter V, round their necks, with their hands tied to the ends of the instrument.

p.#text: How, then, hang-dog. Have you seen them both?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I have seen them.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: I wish you to bring your master to me.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Indeed, I confess that I deserve a very great punishment; and I own that I have done a wrong to your lady guest. But I thought that she was the lady of my master, to whom the Captain, my master, gave me as a keeper; for it is not possible for water ever to be drawn more like to water from the same well, than is she to this lady guest of yours. And I will confess, as well, that I did look through the skylight into your house.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Why shouldn't you confess what I saw myself?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: And there saw in your house this lady guest of yours, kissing.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: You saw her?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I saw her. Why should I deny what I did see? But I fancied that I had seen Philocomasium.

note.#text: :  The old gentleman must surely have changed colour when he said this.

p.#text: And did you suppose me to be the very vilest of all men, in allowing, with my own knowledge, such an injury so glaringly to be done to my neighbour?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Now, at length, I am of opinion that it was done foolishly by me, when I come to understand the matter; but still I did not do it with any ill intent.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Yes, but 'twas improperly done; for it befits a person that is a servant to keep his eyes, and hands, and talk, asleep.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Now, if after this day I mutter anything, even what I know for certain, give me over to torture; I'll give myself up to you. This time, prithee, do pardon me for this.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: I shall subdue my feelings, so as to think that it was not done by you with malicious intent. I will pardon you in this matter.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: May the Gods bless you, then!

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Troth now, as the Gods may prosper you, really do restrain your tongue henceforth; even that which you do know, don't know, and don't you see what you do see.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: You counsel me aright; so I'm resolved to do. Are you quite appeased?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Away with you.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Is there aught else you now require of me?

p.stage: Makes as if he is departing.
p.#text: That you would know me not.

note.#text: :  The "" was a contrivance, by means of joining willow rods, for catching fish. It was probably somewhat in the shape of a large bottle with a narrow mouth, which was placed with a bait in it, facing the current of the stream. See the .

p.#text: . He has been cajoling me. How kindly he vouchsafed his favour not to be angry. I know what plan he is upon: that directly the Captain returns home from the Forum, I may be caught at home. He and Palaestrio together have me in their power: I have perceived that, and for some time I've known it. I' faith, never will I be seeking a bait this day from out of that wicker-net. For now somewhither will I betake myself, and for some days will I lie concealed until this turmoil is hushed and their resentment is softened. Enough punishment for my unlucky prating have I already merited. But still, whatever befals me I'll be off hence home.

note.#text: :  He puns on the word ";" and probably this was a common saying of the day. "" means either "to be wise," or "to have a relishing flavour." Now, inasmuch as the flesh of the pig is of a relishing nature, it may be very truly said, that it has more of the "" in it when dead than alive. In reference to Sceledrus, he seems to mean that he will prove of much more use to their plan now he is bewildered and half deprived of his senses, than when in full possession of his faculties; and that, in fact, so far as their object is concerned, there will be more of the "sapit" in him now than there was before.

:  He calls his fellow-plotters in the mischief, namely, Palaestrio, Philocomasium, and Pleusicles, his Senate, which is now meeting in consultation. When sitting in deliberation, the Senate was said to be "" which may be rendered "sitting," or "full."

:  "" or "" was the distribution by the Senate of the Roman provinces among the Proconsuls. He keeps up the Metaphor of the Senate, and says, that he must make haste, or all the provinces will be distributed; or, in other words, that each party will have agreed on the part he has to play, and will leave him nothing to do.

p.#text: So he has departed hence. I' faith, I know right well, that a dead pig full oft has more relish by far than a living one: so bamboozled has he been, that he did not see what he really did see. For his eyes, and ears, and thoughts have come over to us. So far, 'tis right cleverly managed; the lady has played her part most excellently. I'll go back again to my Senate; for Palaestrio is now at home in my house, and now Sceledrus is gone from the door. A full Senate can now be held. I'll go in; lest while I am absent, there should be a distribution of their parts among them.

div2.stage: Enter PALAESTRIO from the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.

stage: on entering he calls to PLEUSICLES and PERIPLECOMENUS, who are in the house of the latter
Enter PERIPLECOMENUS and PLEUSICLES from the house of the former.

note.#text: :  There was but one Scene throughout the representation of each Roman Comedy. In the present instance, the Scene is in front of the houses of Periplecomenus and the Captain. Nothing can more strikingly show the absurdity of such a plan than the present instance: where Palaestrio comes out of the house of Periplecomenus, for the very purpose, right in front of the house of his own master, of holding a conversation and completing his plot with Pleusicles and Periplecomenus, for the purpose of deceiving his master and carrying off his mistress. With machinery so defective, it is only surprising that the writer completed his task so well as he has done.
: -- , literally "toils with ears."

p.#text: . Keep yourselves within doors, yet a moment, Pleusicles. Let me first look out, that there may be no ambush anywhere, against that council which we intend to hold. For now we have need of a safe place from which no enemy can win the spoils of our counsels. For a well-devised plan is very often filched away, if the place for deliberating has not been chosen with care or with caution; and what is well-advised is ill-advised if it proves of use to the enemy; and if it proves of use to the enemy, it cannot otherwise than prove a detriment to yourself. For if the enemy learn your plans, by your own self-same plans they tie your tongue and bind your hands; and they do the very same to you that you intended to do to them. But I'll spy about, lest any one, either in this direction on the left or on the right, should come like a huntsman on our counsels with his ears like toils.  Quite vacant is the prospect hence right to the bottom of the street. I'll call them out. Hallo! Periplecomenus and Pleusicles, come out!

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Behold us here obedient to your call.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: The sway is easy over the good. But I wish to know, if we are to carry out the matter on the same plan that we formed within?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Why, in fact there's nothing can be more conducive to our purpose. Well, what say you, Pleusicles?

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: Can that displease me which pleases yourselves? What person is there more my friend than your own self?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: You speak kindly and obligingly.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Faith, and so he ought to do.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: But this affair shockingly distresses me, and torments my very heart and body.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: What is it that torments you? Tell me.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: That I should cause childish actions in a person of your years, and that I should require of you deeds that neither become yourself nor your virtues; and that, with all your might, for my sake you are striving to aid me in my passion, and are doing actions of such a kind, as, when done, these years of yours are wont rather to avoid than follow. I am ashamed that I cause you this trouble in your old age.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: You are a person in love after a new fashion. If, in fact, you are ashamed of anything you do, you are nothing of a lover. You are rather the shadow of those who are in love, than a true lover, Pleusicles.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: Ought I to employ these years of yours in seconding my love?

note.#text: :  "," "an inhabitant of Acheron," meaning "one on the very verge of the grave."

:  The bodies of the more respectable people were carried to the grave on a kind of couch, which was called "," or ";" whence the present term "," "a subject for the '.'" The bodies of poor citizens and slaves were carried on a kind of bier, called "." Oudendorp and Becker think, however, that the word "" means "a coffin" of wood or of stone, and not the same as "," a couch, or bier. The old gentleman is very naturally somewhat offended at the remark of Pleusicles.

p.#text: How say you? Do I seem to you so very much a subject for Acheron? So much a bier's-man? Do I seem to you to have had so very long a life? Why, really, I am not more than four-and-fifty years old; I see clearly with my eyes, I'm ready with my hands, I'm active with my feet.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: If he is seen by you to have white hair, he is by no means an old man in mind; in him the natural strength of his mind is unimpaired.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: By my troth, for my part, I have found it to be so as you say, Palaestrio; for, in fact, his kindness is quite that of a young man.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Yes, my guest, the more you make trial of it, the more you will know my courtesy towards you in your love.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: What need to know what's known already?

note.#text: :  The people of , in the south of , were noted for their clownish manners. Animula, as we learn from Festus, was a little town in that country; probably its inhabitants were the most remarkable of all for their rusticity. Absurdities and anachronisms not unfrequently occur in our author. There is something absurd in a merry old gentleman of  going all the way to Animula for a simile.

p.#text: I'll show you more amiability on my part than I'll make mention of * * * * * * * that you may have instances for proving it at home, and not have to seek it out of doors. For unless one has loved himself, with difficulty he sees into the feelings of one in love. But I have some little love and moisture in my body still, and not yet am I dried up for the pursuits of merriment and pleasure. Either the merry banterer likewise, or the agreable boon-companion will I be; no interrupter of another am I at a feast. I bear in mind how properly to keep myself from proving disagreable to my fellow-guests; and how to take a due share with my conversation, and to be silent as well in my turn, when the discourse belongs to another. Far from being a spitter or hawker am I, far from being a dirty-nosed old fellow, too. And never do I take liberties with any person's mistress when out in company; I don't snatch up the dainty bits before another, nor take the cup before my turn; nor, through wine, do dissensions ever arise on my account at the convivial board. If there is any one there that is disagreable, I go off home; I cut the parley short. Stretched at my ease, I devote myself to pleasure, love, and mirth. In fine, at  was I born, not among the Apulians, not at Animula.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: O what a most delightful old man, if he possesses the qualities he mentions! Why, troth, surely now, he was brought up in the very rearing of Venus.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Why, in fact, you will not find another person who is of his years, more accomplished in every respect, or who is more a friend to his friend.

note.#text: :  "" probably signifies here, as in some other passages, a fabulous metal of more value than even gold. "," however, properly means either one of the ores of copper, or a metallic compound much used by the ancients, which was probably brass, formed by the combination of zinc ore and copper. Supposing gold to be one of its constituents, they corrupted its original name, "," into "."
