The former word is supposed by the author of the article "," in Dr. Smith's Dictionary, to have been a compound of  and  "mountain bronze," so called from fusing copper with an ore as found in the mountains. "," in this sentence, has the meaning of "to" or "against," in staking for a bet: "three men against their weight in gold;" "a horse to a hen," as the betting men sometimes say.

p.#text: By my troth, your whole manners really do show marks of first-rate breeding. Find me three men of such manners against a like weight in double-distilled gold.

note.#text: :  Literally, "," one of the names of the West wind.
:  "" cannot be here intended to be used in a bad sense, as he is speaking of his own merits. It must mean "a boon-companion" or "jolly fellow."

p.#text: I'll make you confess that I really am a youngster in my manners; so abounding in kindnesses will I prove myself to you in every respect. Should you have need of an advocate, severe or fierce? I am he. Have you need of one that is gentle? You shall say that I am more gentle than the sea is when hush'd, and something more balmy will I prove than is the Zephyr breeze. In this same person will I display to you either the most jovial boon-companion, or the first-rate trencher-man, and the best of caterers. Then, as for dancing, there is no ballet-master that is so supple as I.
. What could you wish added to these accomplishments, if the option were given you?

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: That thanks could be returned by me to him in degree equal to his deserts, and to yourself, to both of whom I feel that I am now the cause of extreme anxiety. But it is grievous to me to be the cause of so great expense to you.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: You are a simpleton. For, if you lay anything out on a bad wife and upon an enemy, that is an expense; that which is laid out on a deserving guest and a friend is gain; as that, which is expended upon sacred rites, is a profit to the wise man. By the blessing of the Gods, I have enough, with which to receive you with hospitality in my house. Eat, drink, indulge your tastes with me, and surfeit yourself with enjoyments; my house is at your service, myself likewise do I wish to be at your service. For, through the blessing of the Gods, I may say that, by reason of my wealth, I could have married a dowered wife of the best family; but I don't choose to introduce an everlasting female barker at me into my house.

p.#text: Why don't you choose? For 'tis a delightful thing to be the father of children [].

note.#text: :  There is a play on the word "," here, which means either "a child," or "a free person." He says that it is much more pleasant to be "" (a free person), than to be the father of a "" (a child). The word "," meaning "a child," is very rarely used in the singular number. The remark of Pleusicles is rather modified in the translation.
:  The "" was that part of the clothing which was next to the skin.

:  He alludes to the Calends of March, which, as the commencement of the old Roman year, was particularly celebrated by the Roman matrons, who then gave presents to each other, and received them from their husbands. The festival was called "," and sacrifices were offered to Juno Lucina, the guardian of pregnant women. See the .

:  The first day of the "," or "five-day feast," was on the 19th of March. Festus says, that it had its name from its beginning on the fifth day after the Ides. See the . This festival was sacred to Minerva.

:  The "" was a woman who, by her incantations, was powerful to avert evil. "" was a female who interpreted dreams. "" was supposed to be an inspired prophetess. "" was a female who divined by means of the entrails, lightning, and other phenomena. "" was the woman who purified the company and performed the expiations, on the day on which the child received its name.

:  A critic in the St. James's Magazine for January, , says, on this point, that these various importunities, since they relate to a state of things now entirely passed away, lose all their effect on the reader; "but when such insinuating addresses tend to procure a footboy, or a new year's gift, or something handsome to give to servants, or to the wet-nurse, or the Methodist preacher, there is no married man whatever but would enter directly into the spirit of such requests." This sweeping remark may possibly be somewhat less remote from truth than it is from gallantry to the fair sex.
:  "" seems to be "the bed, or mattress-maker." Other editions have "," "the woman who supplies wax candles for sacrifice." Others, again, have "," "the nursemaid that carries the children."
:  The "" were the slaves that were born under the master's roof. They were more indulged than the other slaves, and were noted for their extreme impudence and presumption.
:  The reference here may probably be to the evil eye, which, of injurious effect at all times, would be supposed to be particularly so in the case of a nurse.

p.#text: Troth, 'tis very much sweeter by far to be free [] yourself. For a good wife, if it is possible for her to be married anywhere on earth, where can I find her? But am I to take one home who is never to say this to me, "Buy me some wool, my dear, with which a soft and warm cloak may be made, and good winter under-clothes, that you mayn't catch cold this winter-weather;" such an expression as this you can never hear from a wife, but, before the cocks crow, she awakes me from my sleep, and says, "Give me some money, my dear, with which to make my mother a present on the Calends, give me some money to make preserves; give me something to give on the Quinquatrus to the sorceress, to the woman who interprets the dreams, to the prophetess, and to the female diviner; besides, 'tis impossible for me, in civility, not to fee the expiating woman; for long has the mattress-maker been grumbling, because she has received nothing; besides, the midwife found fault with me, that too little had been sent for her. What! arn't you going to send something to the nurse that brings up the young slaves? It's a shame if nothing's sent her; with what a brow she does look at me." These and many other expenses of the women like to these frighten me from a wife, to be uttering speeches to me like to this.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: In good sooth, the Gods are propitious to you; for so soon as you lose this liberty, you will not easily reinstate yourself in the same condition.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: You are a person who are able to counsel wisely both for another and for yourself. But 'tis some merit for a man of noble family and of ample wealth to rear children--a memorial of his race and of himself.

note.#text: :  It was the custom, after their portions had been sacrificed to the Gods, to reserve a part of the entrails for the persons who sacrificed. These invited their dearest and most intimate friends to partake of them, or, if they could not attend, were in the habit of sending their share to them. The old man here flatters himself that he is a general favorite, although, bye and bye, he hints a suspicion that, being a rich old bachelor, the love of his friends is not quite disinterested.

p.#text: Since I have many relations, what need have I of children? Now I live well and happily, and as I like, and as contents my feelings. For I shall bequeath my property to my relations, and divide it among them. These, like children, pay attentions to me; they come to see how I do, or what I want; before it is daybreak they are with me; they make inquiry how I have enjoyed my sleep in the night. Them will I have for children who are ever sending presents to me. Are they sacrificing--they give a greater part of it to me than to themselves; they take me home with them to share the entrails; they invite me to their houses to breakfast and to dinner. He thinks himself most unfortunate, who has sent but very little to me. They vie with one another with their presents; I say in a low voice to myself: "They are gaping after my property; while, in their emulation, they are nourishing me and loading me with presents."

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Upon right good grounds and right well do you fully understand yourself and your own interests, and if you are happy, sons twofold and threefold have you.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Troth, if I had had them, enough anxiety should I have had from my children. * * * * * * I should have been everlastingly tormented in mind; but if perchance one had had a fever, I think I should have died. Or if one, in liquor, had tumbled anywhere from his horse, I should have been afraid that he had broken his legs or neck on that occasion.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: 'Tis right that riches should come, and that long life should be granted to this man, who both husbands his property and yet enjoys himself and has kind wishes for his friends.

note.#text: :  "" was the name of a public officer among the Greeks, who, like the "" at , had the inspection or the wares offered for sale in the public markets.

p.#text: O what a delightful person! So may the Gods and Goddesses prosper me, 'twere right the Deities should so ordain that all should not live after one rule as to the duration of life. Just as he who is a trusty market-officer sets their prices on the wares; as that which is good or valuable is sold according to its excellence, and that which is worthless, according to the faultiness of the commodity, deprives its owner of its price; so were it right that the Gods should. portion out the life of man, so as to give to him who is kindly disposed a long life, and speedily to deprive of existence those who are reprobate and wicked. If they had provided this, bad men would both have been fewer, and with less hardihood would they do their wicked deeds; and then, those who were good men, of them there would have been a more plenteous harvest.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: He who would blame the ordinances of the Gods must be foolish and ignorant. * * * At present we must at once have an end of these matters; for new I want to go to market, that, my guest, according to your own deserts and mine, I may entertain you hospitably at my house, heartily and with right hearty cheer.

note.#text: :  ";" "I am not dissatisfied with."

p.#text: I am content with the expense that I have been to you already. For no guest can be thus hospitably entertained by a friend, but that when he has been there three days running, he must now become a bore; but when he is prolonging his stay for ten successive days, he is a nuisance to the household. Although the master willingly allows it, the servants grumble.

note.#text: :  ";" literally, "I carry on my own business with my own staff of rowers." The rowers were frequently slaves, and of course were kept in strict subordination. He alludes to the regularity of his household, where everything is done in its proper time and place, and the promptness with which he is in the habit of being obeyed. We need hardly remark that most of the "," or "servants," were slaves.

p.#text: I have trained up the servants that are in my service, my guest, not to rule over me, or for me to be obedient to them. If that is disagreable to them which is agreable to me, I steer my own course; that which they don't like must still be done at their peril, and whether they like it or no. Now, as I intended, I shall go to market.

note.#text: :  "" seem to have been an antiquated and hackneyed expression, used by philosophers and old-fashioned people, to imply their habits of self-denial and frugality.

p.#text: If you are resolved, do cater somewhat within bounds, at no great expense; anything is enough for me.

note.#text: :  He tells him to have done with such stale canting expressions, which are now worn threadbare, and have descended to the tables of the mob. Indeed, he says right, for nothing can be more annoying than pretended refusals, and bowings and scrapings, where they are merely an affectation of a modesty, humility, or self-denial that is not really felt.
:  The "" were the poorest class of the free citizens, who, according to Livy, were possessed of less than eleven thousand "," and could serve the state, not with money, but with their children ().

p.#text: Won't you now have done with that old-fashioned and antiquated talk? Now surely, guest, you are using the cant of the vulgar. For they are in the habit of saying, when they have taken their places, when dinner is put on table: "What necessity was there for you to go to this great expense on out account? Surely you were mad, for this same dinner was enough for ten persons." What has been provided on their account they find fault with; they eat it up, however.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Troth, in that self-same fashion 'tis generally done. How clever and shrewd is his discernment.

note.#text: :  Lampreys and conger eels were very much esteemed by the Romans. Probably the conger was considered best when eaten cold.
:  This would be the more easily done when we remember that the guests were reclining on the "," or couch, which was above the level of the table on which the viands were placed.

p.#text: But these same persons never say, although such an abundance has been provided, "Do order that to be taken off; do take away this dish; remove this gammon of bacon, I'll have none of it; put aside that piece of pork; this conger's good when cold; remove it, take and put it aside." You hear none of them saying this in earnest, but they stretch themselves out, while with half their bodies on the table, they are indulging their appetite.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: How cleverly the good soul has described their bad manners.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: I have not said a hundredth part of what I could have enlarged upon had there been leisure for the matter.

note.#text: :  By his mention of the Captain's long locks, he seems to intend a pun on the word "," "to bamboozle" or "cajole," which, literally, signifies to "clip," or "shave close."

p.#text: The business, then, that we are about--to that we ought first to turn our thoughts. Do you both, now, give me your attention. I have need, Periplecomenus, of your assistance; for I have hit upon a pleasant trick, how this Captain with his long locks may be fleeced quite close, and how we may effect a means for Philocomasium, and this her lover, that he may carry her off hence, and have her as his own.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: I wish this plan to be imparted to me.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: And I, wish that ring of yours to be imparted to me.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: For what purpose is it to be used?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: When I have got it, I will impart the plan of my devices.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Take and use it. (Gives him the ring.)

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Take from me in return the plan of my contrivance that I have hit upon.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: We are listening to you with most attentive ear.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: My master is such a shocking rake among the women, that I think no one ever was his equal, nor ever will be.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: I believe the same as well.

note.#text: :  "Alexander," from two Greek words, signifying "the brave man," was one of the names of , the son of Priam, who was remarkable for his beauty, which captivated Helen.
:  The Parasite quizzes him upon this weak point in the First Act.

p.#text: He boasts, too, that his beauty exceeds that of Alexander; and, therefore, he says that all the women in  of their own accord are courting him.

note.#text: :  The meaning of Periplecomenus seems to be that the Captain has been but too successful in his intrigues, and that many a husband could wish that what Palaestrio says were false.

p.#text: Aye, faith, many there are who could wish that you were now telling an untruth about him. But I am convinced full well that it is as you say. For that reason, Palaestrio, do compress your words in as short a compass as ever you possibly can.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Can you, then, find any woman of agreable person, whose mind and body are full of merriment and subtlety?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Free by birth, or bondwoman made free?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I consider that a matter of indifference, so that you find one who is greedy for gain, who supports her body by her charms, who has, too, her senses all awake; as for her heart, that cannot be so, as none of them have one.

note.#text: :  Some Commentators think that "" here means "one who has borne children," and who has bathed (), as was the custom immediately after delivery. As, however, Palaestrio has said before that the female required must be a Courtesan, it surely could not matter whether she had had children or not. It probably means either one of elegant manners, and who has made good use of her experience, in contradistinction to a novice, who is a mere raw country wench, or else one in easy circumstances, and not a mere pauper.

p.#text: Do you want one that has taken her degrees, or one as yet a novice in the art?

note.#text: :  His answer is, he wants to find a woman who is "," probably in the sense of "sober;" but, as the same word means "dry," he adds, antithetically, "," "but juicy," full of the plumpness and briskness of youth. Scaliger absolutely thinks that "" means "one not given to the habit of spitting."!!

p.#text: One sober but plump, a juicy bit; as taking a one as ever you can find, and one very young.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Why, I have one, a dependant of mine, a courtesan, a very young woman. But what is the occasion for her?

note.#text: :  The "" was a band which encircled the head, and served to confine the tresses of the hair. It was worn by maidens, and by married women also, among the Romans; but that assumed on the day of marriage was of a different form from that used by the virgins. It was not worn by women of light character, or even by the "," or liberated female slaves; so that it was not only deemed an emblem of chastity, but of freedom also.  White and purple are among the colours of the "" which we find mentioned.

p.#text: For you to bring her home at once to your house as your wife, and, for that reason, to bring her there dressed out, so that she may wear her locks with her hair arranged, and fillets after the fashion of matrons, and may pretend that she is your wife; so you must instruct her.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: I am at a loss what road you are taking.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Well, you shall know. But what sort of a maid has she?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: She is a rare clever one.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: We have need of her as well; so give your instructions to the damsel and her maid, to pretend that she is your wife and is doting upon this Captain; and as though she had given this ring to her maid, then she to me, that I might deliver it to the Captain; and I must be as though it were a go-between in this matter.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: I hear you; don't stun my ears as if I were deaf.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I myself will go straightway to him; I'll say that it has been brought and delivered to me from your wife, in order that I might introduce her to him. He'll be distractedly longing for her at home, a scoundrel that cares for nothing else whatever but intriguing.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: If you had commissioned the Sun himself to search them out, he couldn't have found, better than myself, two more cleverly suited for this business. Be of good courage about it.

p.#text: Take you every care then. There is need of despatch.
Now, do you listen, Pleusicles.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: I am all attention to you.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Take care of this. When the Captain comes home, do you remember not to call Philocomasium by her name.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: What am I to call her?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Glycera.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: The same, you mean, that was agreed upon a little time since.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Hush!--Be off.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: I'll remember; but still I don't know what use it is to keep it in my mind.

note.#text: :  He alludes to Periplecomenus, who has just left him.

p.#text: But I will tell you, at the time, when occasion shall require. Meanwhile, be quiet; so that, bye and bye, when he too shall be acting his part, you may, on the instant, be minding your cue.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: I'll go in then.

p.stage: PLEUSICLES goes into the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.
p.#text: Go, and do take care steadily to follow my instructions.

note.#text: :  "" was a term applied to the common soldiers of the legion, inasmuch as they were formed into small companies, marshalled in open order, called "." Each maniple had two centurions, whose duty it was to drill their men, inspect their arms, clothing, and food, visit the sentinels, and regulate the conduct of the privates both in the camp and in the field. They sat as judges in minor offences, and had the power of ordering corporal punishment, whence their badge of office was a vine sapling.  "" consequently means here "well drilled."

stage: Goes to the door and calls.
Enter LUCRIO from the CAPTAIN's house.
p.#text: What mighty turmoils I create! What mighty engines 1 do set to work! This very day I shall take his mistress away from the Captain, if my soldiers are only well drilled. But I'll call him out.  ! Sceledrus, if you are not busy, come out to the front of the house; I, Palaestrio, call you.

sp.speaker: LUCRIO
sp.p: Sceledrus is not at leisure.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Why so?

note.#text: :  "" means not only "to drink up," but to make that gulping noise in snoring which is produced by inhaling the breath with the mouth open, and the head thrown back. Palaestrio purposely misunderstands him, for the purpose of getting a confession out of him.

p.#text: He's fast asleep, gulping.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: How, gulping?

sp.speaker: LUCRIO
sp.p: He's snoring, 'twas that I meant to say: but, because 'tis very like gulping when you are snoring---- * * * * * * *

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What ! Is Sceledrus asleep in-doors?

sp.speaker: LUCRIO
sp.p: Not with his nose, in fact; for with that he is calling out loud enough.

note.#text: :  According to the reading here adopted, he guesses that Sceledrus has got drunk upon some nardine wine, that had been lately tapped. The Romans used many articles for flavouring their wines. Spikenard, an Eastern aromatic, is here referred to. Horehound, squills, wormwood, and myrtle-berries were used for making medical wines. Cornels, figs, medlars, roses, asparagus, parsley, radishes, laurels, junipers, cassia, cinnamon, and saffron, with many other particulars, were also used for flavouring wines.

:  Some Commentators take this passage to mean, that Sceledrus really was the "," or "butler;" but it seems more probable that Palaestrio says, by way of accusation, "Sceledrus has not only been acting the butler on this occasion, but you have been acting as his deputy, in secretly helping him to draw it." Lucrio was the "" of Sceledrus, the "deputy-keeper" of Philocomasium, and the under-butler as well.

p.#text: He has taken a cup by stealth; the butler has lately tapped a cask of nardine. Oho! you rascal, you are his deputy-butler. Oho!

sp.speaker: LUCRIO
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: How has he thought fit to go to sleep?

sp.speaker: LUCRIO
sp.p: With his eyes, I suppose.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I don't ask you that, you vagabond. Step this way: you're undone now, unless I know the truth. Did you draw the wine for him?

sp.speaker: LUCRIO
sp.p: I did not draw it.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Do you deny it?

note.#text: :  He adheres to his promise by denying it in words, but m such a way as to make a full confession of what has happened. "" was a measure among the Greeks and Romans of nearly half a pint.

:  It has been already remarked, that the Romans were much in the habit of drinking wine, made warm and mixed with spices. The taking it at "," about twelve in the day, shows how Sceledrus presumed on the office of trust which had been conferred upon him.

p.#text: I' faith, I do deny it undoubtedly; for he charged me not to tell. I really didn't just draw for him eight half pints into a pitcher, and, when drawn, he didn't just drink it hot, at his breakfast.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: And you didn't just drink as well?

sp.speaker: LUCRIO
sp.p: The Gods confound me if I did drink--if I could drink.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: LUCRIO
sp.p: Because, in fact, I only sipped; for it was too hot; it burnt my throat.

note.#text: :  "" was the name of the mixture of vinegar and water which constituted the drink of the Roman soldiers, the lower classes, and the slaves. Palaestrio grumbles on finding that while he is drinking vinegar and water his fellow-slave is enjoying himself on mulled wine.

p.#text: Some are gloriously drunk, while others are drinking vinegar-water. The cellar's trusted to an honest butler, as well as under-butler.

sp.speaker: LUCRIO
sp.p: I' faith, you'd be doing the same, if it was entrusted to you. Since you can't follow our example, you are envious now.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Come, now, did he ever draw any wine before this? Answer me, you rascal. And, that you may understand it, I give you this notice: if you purposely tell me an untruth, you shall be put to the torture.

sp.speaker: LUCRIO
sp.p: Indeed so? That you may inform, forsooth, that I told you; and then I shall be turned out of my fattening post in the cellar, that you may find another under-butler to draw for your own self.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: On my honour, I will not; come, speak out boldly to me.

sp.speaker: LUCRIO
sp.p: By my troth, I never saw him draw any. But thus was it; he requested me, and then I drew it.

note.#text: :  He means to say that the "," no doubt, were often turned bottom upwards for the purpose of pouring out their contents.

p.#text: Think of that now! very frequently, I guess, the casks were standing on their heads there.

note.#text: :  The whole of this passage is of somewhat obscure signification. The two lines probably mean, "The casks () would not have fallen down there so very much, had it not been that one part of the cellar was very slippery indeed." He then shows how () the pot was put close by the casks, so that, they slipping down, it was filled as often as ten times in one day; and he concludes by saying, that when the pot acted the Bacchanal (), the casks slipped down again. Probably by acting the Bacchanal he means to say that the pot got filled and was then emptied, just like the Bacchanals, who, doubtless, were not particular at vomiting a part of the enormous quantities of wine which they imbibed; and he naively tells the truth, by saying that the cask slipping was the result of the pot being emptied, and so laying the fault more upon the pot than the drinker.

p.#text: No, faith, the casks would not have stood so very badly there. But there happened to be in the cellar a bit of a slippery spot; a two-pint pot was placed there, near the casks, in this fashion . Frequently, that was filled ten times in a day. When the pot acted the reveller, the casks were all tottering.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Get you gone in-doors. Both of you, I find, are acting the revellers in the wine-cellar. I' faith, I shall fetch my master home just now from the Forum.

note.#text: :  These occasional addresses to the Spectators, in the middle of the dialogue, were made in the same spirit and for the same purpose for which the clown on our stage addresses his jokes to the audience, namely, to provoke a hearty laugh.

p.#text: . I'm ruined. My master, when he comes home, will have me tortured, when he knows of these doings. I' faith, I'll fly somewhither, and put off this punishment to another day.  Don't you tell him, I do entreat you most earnestly.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Whither are you betaking yourself?

sp.speaker: LUCRIO
sp.p: I am sent elsewhere: I'll come back here just now.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Who has sent you?

sp.speaker: LUCRIO
sp.p: Philocomasium.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Go; be back directly.

p.#text: If it is divided, prithee do you only take my share of the punishment while I'm away.

note.#text: :  By the use of the word , he probably refers to the assumed stateliness of her gait.

p.#text: So--I understand what scheme the lady is upon. Because Sceledrus is asleep, she has sent her under-keeper away out of doors, whilst she may pass from our house to next door. That's all right.  But Periplecomenus is bringing here a woman of very comely appearance, her, for whom I commissioned him. By my faith, the Gods are helping us in this matter. How becomingly drest she struts along, not like a Courtesan. This business is prospering charmingly in our hands.

div2.stage: Enter PERIPLECOMENUS, with ACROTELEUTIUM and MILPHIDIPPA.

p.#text: . I have explained the whole affair, Acroteleutium, to you, and, Milphidippa, to you as well. If you don't well understand this device and plan, I wish you to hear it all over again. If you comprehend it aright, there is something else that we may speak of in preference.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: I' faith, it would be folly, and ignorance, and foolishness, for me to engage in the service of another, or to promise you my assistance, if, in its fabrication, I did not know how to be either mischievous or clever at deceiving.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: But, 'tis better for you to be instructed.

note.#text: :  "." The true meaning of this word seems to be "a leather bottle." If it is the correct reading, it is here used by Metonymy for the draught which it contains.

p.#text: Really I don't understand of what great use it is for a Courtesan to be instructed. How now! have I told you all in vain, after my ears had drunk in the draughts of your discourse, in what fashion it was possible for the Captain to be cajoled?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: But no one, unaided, is sufficiently perfect; for full oft have I seen many a person lose the road to good advice before they had found it.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: If a woman has anything to do mischievously and maliciously, in that case her memory is immortal at remembering it for everlasting; but if anything is to be done for a good purpose, or honestly, it will fall out that those same women will become oblivious that instant, and be unable to remember.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Therefore do I fear that same, because both those things happen to be about to be done by us; for that will be a benefit to me in which you both will be acting mischievously towards the Captain.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: So long as we do anything that's good, not knowing it, don't you fear. No woman is awkward * * * * * * Have no apprehensions, they are ready for the worst.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: So it befits you. Do you follow me.

p.#text: . Why do I hesitate to go and accost them?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Well met, and opportunely, Palaestrio. See, here they are whom you commissioned me to bring, and in the very dress.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Well done: accept my thanks. I am glad that you have come safe. I' faith, you bring them nicely dressed Palaestrio salutes Acroteleutium.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: Prithee, who's this, that calls me so familiarly by name?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: This is our master-plotter.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: Health to you, master-plotter.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: And health to you. But, tell me, has he any way given you full instructions?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: I bring them both thoroughly prepared.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I'd like to hear how. I'm afraid lest you should be making some mistake.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: I have added to your instructions nothing new of my own.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: I suppose you wish the Captain, your master, to be gulled.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: You've said what's true.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: Cleverly and skilfully, adroitly and pleasantly, the whole thing is planned.

p.#text: In fact, I wish you to pretend to be his wife.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: That shall be done.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: To pretend as though you had set your affection on the Captain.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: And so it shall be.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: And as though this affair is managed through me, as the go-between, and your servant-maid.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: You might have made a good prophet; for you tell what is to be.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: As though this maid of yours had conveyed from you this ring to me, which I was then to deliver to the Captain, in your name.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: You say what's true.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: What need is there to mention these things now, which they remember so well?

note.#text: :  Lambinus has thus explained this metaphorical expression. The ship is the contrivance for deceiving the Captain; the keel is the main-plot and foundation of it; Periplecomenus, Acroteleutium, and her servant, are the workmen; Palaestrio is the master-shipwright; while the Captain himself is the "" or "person that supplies the timber."

p.#text: Still, it is better. For think of this, my patron; when the shipwright is skilful, if he has once laid down the keel exact to its lines, 'tis easy to build the ship, when * * * * Now this keel of ours has been skilfully laid and firmly placed; the workmen and the master-builders are not unskilled in this business. If he who furnishes the timber does not retard us in giving what is needed, I know the adroitness of our ingenuity--soon will the ship be got ready.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: You know the Captain, my master, then?

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: 'Tis strange you should ask me. How could I not know that scorn of the public, that swaggering, frizzle-headed, perfumed debauchee?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: But does he know you?

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: He never saw me: how, then, should he know who I am?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: 'Tis most excellent what you say. For that reason, i' faith, the thing will be able to be managed all the more cleverly.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: Can you only find me the man, and then be easy as to the rest? If I don't make a fool of the fellow, do you lay all the blame on me.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Well, go you in then; apply yourselves to this business with all your skill.

note.#text: :  ";" literally, "take care of something else; meaning, "trust us in the present instance," or, as  expresses it, "never fear us."

p.#text: Trust me for that.

Come, Periplecomenus, do you conduct them at once in-doors. I'm off to the Forum; I'll meet him, and give him this ring, and will tell him that it has been delivered to me from your wife, and that she is dying for him. As soon as we shall have come from the Forum, do you send her  to our house as though she were privately sent to him.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: We'll do so; trust us for that.

p.#text: Do you only attend to the business; I'll now polish him off with a pretty burden on his back.

Go, with good luck to you, manage the matter cleverly.  But now, if I shall manage this adroitly, that my guest can this day gain the mistress of the Captain, and carry her off hence to ; if, I say, this day we shall succeed in this plan, what shall I give you for a present?

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: * * * * * If now the lady seconds our efforts on her part, I think it will be right cleverly and adroitly managed. When a comparison shall be made of our artifices, I have no fear that I shall not prove superior in the cleverness of my contrivances.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Let's go in-doors, then, that we may deeply weigh these plans, that carefully and cautiously we may carry out what is to be done, so that, when the Captain comes, there may be no tripping.

p.stage: They go into the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.
p.#text: You are delaying us with your talk.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: 'Tis a pleasure what you do, if it succeeds agreably and to your mind. For I this day have sent my Parasite to King Seleucus, to lead those soldiers, that I have levied, hence to Seleucus; in order that they may defend his kingdom till I have leisure to attend in person.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Why don't you attend to your own concerns rather than those of Seleucus. What a charming new proposal is being offered to you through me as the negotiator.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Well then, I lay all other things aside, and I give my attention to you. Speak out: my ears, in fact, I surrender at your disposal.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Look around, then, that no one here may be an eavesdropper for our discourse; for this business was entrusted me to transact with you in private.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: (looks around). There's no one near.

p.#text: In the first place, receive from me this pledge of affection.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What's this? Whence comes it?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: From a charming and a handsome lady, one who loves you, and dotes upon your extreme beauty. Her maid just now gave me the ring that I might then give it to you.

note.#text: :  "" is the same with "," the rod, or wand, which the Praetor used to lay on the head of the s.ave when he was made free.

p.#text: What? Is she free born or a freed woman, made free from a slave by the Praetor's rod?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Pshaw! Should I presume to be the bearer of a message to you from a person once a slave, who cannot sufficiently answer the demands of the free women who are longing for you?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Is she wife, or is she widow?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: She is both wife and widow.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: In what way is it possible for the same woman to be a wife and a widow?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Because she is a young woman married to an old man.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: That's good.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: She is of genteel and charming person.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Beware of misrepresenting.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: It is alone worthy to be compared with your own charms.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: By my faith, you make her out to be a beauty. But who is she?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: The wife of that old gentleman, Periplecomenus, next door. She is dying for you, and wishes to leave him; she hates the old fellow. Now she has begged me to entreat and beseech you that you will give her your support and assistance.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I' faith, I'm ready for my part if she desires it.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Doesn't she long for it?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What shall we do with that mistress of mine, who is at my house?

p.#text: Why, do you bid her to be gone about her business, wherever she chooses; as her twin-sister has come here to , and her mother, and they are come to fetch her.
Ha! what's that you say? Has her mother come to ?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Those say so who know it.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I' faith, a charming opportunity for me to turn the wench out of doors.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Aye, but do you wish to do the thing handsomely?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Speak out, and give me your advice.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Do you wish to pack her off forthwith, that she may quit you with a good grace?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I do so wish.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Then this is the thing you must do. You have a superabundance of wealth; bid the woman to keep as a present for herself the gold and trinkets which you have supplied her with, and to take herself off from your house wherever she likes.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: It pleases me what you say; but yet, only think, if I should lose her, and the other change her mind?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Pshaw! you're over nice; a lady, that loves you as her own eyes.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Venus befriends me.

p.stage: MILPHIDIPPA comes out of the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.
p.#text: Hist! hush! the door is opening; come this way a little out of sight.  This is her fly-boat-her go-between, that's coming out there.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: How so--fly-boat?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: This is her maid that is coming ut of the house, she that brought that ring which I delivere to you.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I' faith, she too is a prettyish wench.

note.#text: :  "" was the name of some ugly, ill-omened bird; of what kind it is not now known.

p.#text: This one is a little monkey and an owl in comparison with the other. Do you see how she hunts around with her eyes, and goes fowling about with her ears.

note.#text: :  This is an allusion to the Circus at , where the public games were exhibited.

p.#text: . My Circus, then, is before the house, where my sports are to take place. I'll make pretence, as though I didn't see them, or knew as yet that they are here.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Hush! let's quietly listen, whether any mention is made of me.

note.#text: :  "" is properly applied to a birdcatcher, or fowler, who watches his nets.

:  "." She is supposed to mean those who are not out on the hunt for a supper, but have got one of their own at home. These latter persons, she thinks, living at their ease, and not having to satisfy a hungry stomach, are likely to have more leisure for prying into the concerns of other people, than those who are put to their shifts for a meal.

p.#text: . Is there no one near at hand here, to attend to another's business rather than his own?--to prowl after me to see what I'm about? No one who is feeding this evening at his own expense? I dread such men as these, lest they should now come in the way, or prove an hindrance somehow, should my mistress privately pass from her house this way, who is so enamoured of his person, who so dotes upon this very charming man with his exceeding beauty--the Captain Pyrgopolinices

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: And doesn't she dote upon me, too? She is praising my beauty.

note.#text: :  He says that she is so very clean spoken () that she needs no ashes with which to scour her words; the figure being derived from the custom of scouring brass vessels with pounded ashes.

p.#text: I' faith, her language stands in need of no ashes.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: For what reason?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Why, because her language is clean spoken and far from slovenly. Whatever she says about yourself, she handles it in no slovenly way. And, then, besides, she herself is a very pretty and a very dainty wench.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Troth, indeed, she has made an impression already, Palaestrio, at first sight.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What! before you have seen the other with your eyes?

note.#text: :  The "" was probably a delicate fish, whose name is now unknown, but not so much so as the "mullus," the "grey mullet," which was very highly esteemed by the Roman epicures.

p.#text: What I see, in that I have faith for myself; for this mackerel, in the absence of the mullet, compels me to be in love with her.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I' faith, you really mustn't be falling in love with her, she's engaged to me. If the other weds you to-day, forthwith I shall take this one for my wife.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Why, then, do you delay to accost her?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Follow me this way, then.

note.#text: :  "." The "" were a class of slaves at  whose duty it was to walk behind their master when he went out of doors. The name does not seem to have been given to every slave who followed his master, but they belonged to a class which was almost the lowest in the slave family.

p.#text: I am your lackey at your heels.
. I wish that I had an opportunity of meeting him on account of whom I came here out of doors.
. It shall be so, and you shall have what you so greatly wish; be of good courage, don't fear; there is a certain person who knows where that is which you are seeking.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: Who's that I hear at hand?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: The sharer of your plans and the partaker of your secrets.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: I' faith, then, what I do conceal I don't conceal.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Aye, but still you don't conceal it this way.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: From the uninitiated you conceal them. I am sure and trustworthy to you.

note.#text: :  "." Literally, "one of the "Bacchae," or "votaries of Bacchus." Only those were admitted to the rites who had been duly initiated. These had a sign or password called "," or "," by which they recognised each other, and thus Milphidippa asks Palaestrio to give her some proof that he is the right person for her to address. This pretended caution is only assumed in the Captain's presence, in order the better to impose upon him, by affecting the utmost care and secrecy in the matter

p.#text: Give me the sign, if you are one of these votaries.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: A certain lady loves a certain gentleman.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: Faith, many ladies do that indeed.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: But not many ladies send a present from off their fingers.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: Aye, I know now. You've now made the matter level for me instead of steep. But is there a certain person here?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Either he is or he is not.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: Come aside with me alone, in private.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: For a short or for a lengthy conversation?

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: For three words only.

p.#text: . I'll return to you this instant.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What? Shall I be standing here in the meanwhile, with such charms and valorous deeds, thus to no purpose?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Submit to it and wait; for you am I doing this service.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Make haste; I am tortured with waiting.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: You know that commodities of this kind are only wont to be reached step by step.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Well, well; as is most agreable to yourself.

p.#text: . There is no stone more stupid than this fellow. I now return to you.  What would you with me?

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: In the way in which I received it of you a short time since, I bring you back your clever lot; my story is as though she were dying with love for him.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: That 1 understand. Do you commend his beauty and his appearance, and make mention of his prowess.

note.#text: :  "." Literally, "I have all my troops in battle array."
:  "." Literally, "hunt out," or "act the hunter's part," probably with reference to starting the game.

p.#text: For that purpose I am armed at all points, as I have shown you before already. On the other hand, do you give all attention, and be on the watch, and take your cue from my words.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Prithee do now, in fine, give me some share in the business; step this way this instant, I beg.

p.#text: . Here I am. If you wish for aught, give me your commands.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What is she saying to you?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: She is saying that her mistress is lamenting, and, in tears, is tormenting and afflicting herself because she wishes for you, and because she possesses you not; for that reason has she been sent here to you.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Bid her approach.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: But do you know how you are to act? Pretend that you are full of disdain, as though it pleased you not; exclaim against me, because I make you so common to the mob.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I remember, and I'll follow your instructions.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I'll call her, then, who is inquiring after you.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: If she wants anything, let her come.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Wench, if you want anything, step this way.

note.#text: :  "." "Handsome man." This, as a surname, would not sound so very absurd in Roman ears, as "Pulcher" was a surname (cognomen) of a branch of the Claudian family.

p.#text: . Save you, charmer.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: She makes mention of my surname. May the Gods grant you whatever you may desire.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: To pass life with you is the wish of----

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: You are wishing too much.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: I am not speaking of myself, but of my mistress, who is dying for you.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Many others are wishing for the same thing, who have not the opportunity.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: By my troth, 'tis not to be wondered at; you set a high value on yourself--a person so handsome, and so illustrious for his prowess, and so valorous in his deeds! O! was there ever any one more worthy to be a man?

note.#text: : , He probably alludes to the fact of the vulture sometimes carrying human flesh in its maw

p.#text: . I' faith, the filthy fellow is not a human being; indeed, I think there is something more human in a vulture.
. Now I shall make myself of importance, since she so praises me up.
. Do you see the blockhead, how he struts?  But will you not answer her; she is the woman that's come from the lady whom I was mentioning just now.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: But from which one of them? For there are so many courting me, I cannot remember them all.

p.#text: From her who strips her own fingers and adorns your fingers; for I delivered to him  that ring from her who is sighing for you, and then he to you.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Tell me, wench, what is it you want then?

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: That you will not despise her who is sighing for you; who lives now but in your life: whether she is to exist or not, her hope is in you alone.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What does she want then?

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: To talk with you, to embrace you, and to be intimate with you. For unless you bring her succour, she will soon be quite desponding in her mind. Come, my Achilles, let that be done which I entreat; save her, charmer, by your charming ways. Call forth your kind disposition, stormer of cities, slayer of kings.

p.#text: O! by my troth, 'tis a vexatious thing!  How often, whip-scoundrel, have I forbidden you to make promises of my attention thus common.

note.#text: :  This passage is somewhat nodified in the translation.

p.#text: Do you hear that, hussy? I have told you already, and I now tell you again, unless a fee is given to this boar- pig, he cannot possibly throw away his attentions in any quarter.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: A fee shall be given, as large as he shall demand.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: He requires a talent of gold, in Philippean pieces. Less he will take from no one.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: O, by my troth, but that's too little, surely.

note.#text: :  The "" was a Roman measure one-third of the "." It contained nearly two English gallons.

p.#text: By nature there's no avarice in me; I have riches enough. I' faith! I've more than a thousand measures full of Philippean gold coins.
Besides your treasures. Then, of silver, he has mountains, not ingots;  is not so high.
. By the stars! O, what a lie!
. How rarely I am playing him off!
. And I; how do I do it? Ain't I gulling him?
. Rarely.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: But, prithee, do let me go now.

p.#text: . But do you give her some answer, either that you will do it, or that you won't do it. Why cause this poor lady so much anguish of mind, who has never deserved any ill of you?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Bid her come to me herself. Tell her that I will do everything that she requires.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: You now act as it is proper for you to act. since you wish the same yourself that she is wishing.

p.#text: . No poor faculty of invention has she.
Since too you have not scouted your petitioner, and nave suffered me to prevail upon you.  How now? Haven't I played him off?
. Faith, I couldn't refrain from laughing.
. Yes; and for the same reason I turned in this direction away from you.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: By my troth, wench, you don't understand how great an honor I am now paying her.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: I know, and I shall tell her so.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: To another he could have sold his favours for his weight in gold.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: I' faith, I believe you in that.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Of those that are parents by him true warriors are born, and his sons live eight hundred years.

p.#text: . Fie on you for a fibber!

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Why, straight on, from age to age, they live for a thousand years.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I spoke within limits, for the reason that she mightn't suppose I was telling lies to her.

p.#text: . I burst, I die!  How many years will he live himself whose sons live so long?
Wench, I was born the day after  was born of Ops.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: If he had only been born the day before the other was, he would have had the realms of heaven.

p.#text: . Now, now, prithee, no more do let me get away from you, if I can, alive.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Why don't you go then, as you have your answer?

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: I'll go, and I'll bring her here, on whose behalf I am employed. Is there aught else you wish?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: May I never be more handsome than I am at pre sent; so much trouble do my good looks cause me.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Why do you stay now? Why don't you go?

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: I'm going.

p.#text: . And tell her, too, do you hear, cleverly and correctly, what has passed.
. So that her very heart may leap for joy.
If Philocomasium is there, tell her to pass through into our house; that the Captain here.

p.#text: . She is there with my mistress for, on the sly, they have been overhearing this conversation.
. 'Twas cleverly done; here after they will take their cue the more readily from this conversation.
. You are delaying me. I'm off.

note.#text: :  This is an instance of Aposiopesis.  He is about to say something rude, but checks himself.

p.#text: . I'm not delaying you, nor touching you, nor--I'm mum.

p.stage: MILPHIDIPPA goes into the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.
p.#text: Bid her make haste to come out here; we'll give our first attention to this matter especially.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What do you advise me now to do, Palaestrio, about my mistress? For this lady can by no means be received into my house before I have sent the other away.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Why consult me what you are to do? So far as I am concerned, I have told you by what method that can be effected in the gentlest manner. The gold trinkets and female clothing with which you have furnished her, let her keep it all for herself: let her take it, be off, and carry it away: tell her that it is high time for her to go home; say that her twin-sister and her mother are come, in company with whom she may go straight home.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: How do you know that they are here?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Because, with my own eyes, I've seen her sister here.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Have you met her?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I have met her.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: And did she seem a brisk wench?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: You are wishing to have everything.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Where did the sister say her mother was?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: The captain that brought them told me that she was in bed, on board the ship, with sore and inflamed eyes. This captain of the ship is lodging with them next door.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: And he, too, is he a very fine fellow?

note.#text: :  This passage is somewhat modified above.

p.#text: Away with you, if you please. What have you to do with him? You have your hands quite full enough with the women. Attend to this for the present.

note.#text: :  He thinks it not suitable to his dignity to speak on the subject himself, and therefore wishes to put the task upon Palaestrio.

p.#text: As to that advice you were giving me, I wish you to have a few words with her upon that subject. For, really, a conversation on that subject with her is more becoming for you.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What is more advisable than for you to go yourself, and transact your own concerns? You must say that it is absolutely necessary for you to marry: that your relations are persuading, your friends are urging, you.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: And do you think so?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Why shouldn't I think so?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I'll go in, then. Do you, in the mean time, keep watch here before the house, that when the other woman comes out you may call me out.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Do you only mind the business that you are upon.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: That, indeed, is resolved upon. For if she will not go out of her own accord, I'll turn her out by force.

note.#text: :  "." "" was a legal term used in the case of amicable divorces with the consent of both parties.

p.#text: Do you take care how you do that; but rather let her go from your house with a good grace, and give her those things that I mentioned. The gold trinkets and apparel, with which you furnished her, let her take away.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: By my troth, I wish she would.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I think you'll easily prevail upon her. But go indoors; don't linger here.

p.#text: I obey you. .

. Now, does he really appear to be anything different from what, awhile ago, I told you he was, this wenching Captain? Now it is requisite that Acroteleutium should come to me, her maid too, and Pleusicles. O ! and does not opportunity favour me in every respect? For those whom I especially wished to see, I perceive at this moment coming out here from our neighbour's.

div2.stage: Enter ACROTELEUTIUM, MILPHIDIPPA, and PLEUSICLES from the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: Follow me; at the same time look around, that there may be no overlooker.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: Faith, I see no one, only him whom we want to meet.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Just as I want you.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: How do you do, our master-plotter?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I, the master-plotter? Nonsense.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Because, in comparison with yourself, I am not worthy to fix a beam in a wall.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: Aye, indeed so.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: She's a very fluent and a very clever hand at mischief. How charmingly she did polish off the Captain.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: But still, not enough.

p.#text: Be of good courage all the business is now prospering under our hands. Only do you, as you have begun, still give a helping hand; for the Captain himself has gone in-doors, to entreat his mistress to leave his house, with her mother and sister, for .

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: Very good--well done.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Besides, all the gold trinkets and apparel which he himself has provided for the damsel, he gives her to keep as a present for herself--so have I recommended him.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: Really, it's easily done, if both she wishes it, and he desires it as well.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Don't you know that when, from a deep well, you have ascended up to the top, there is the greatest danger lest you should thence fall back again from the top. This affair is now being carried on at the top of the well. If the Captain should have a suspicion of it, nothing whatever of his will be able to be carried off. Now, most especially, we have need of clever contrivances.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: I see that there is material enough at home for that purpose--three women, yourself the fourth, I am the fifth, the old gentleman the sixth.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What an edifice of stratagems has been erected by us! I know for certain. that any town seems as though it could be taken by these plans: only do you lend your assistance.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: For that purpose are we come to you, to see if you wish for anything.

note.#text: :  "." This term was properly applied to the Senate when bestowing a province upon a Proconsul or Propraetor.

p.#text: You do what's  propos. Now to you do I assign this department.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: General, you shall assign me whatever you please, so far as I am capable.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I wish this Captain to be played off cleverly and adroitly.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: I' faith, you're assigning me what's a pleasure to me.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: But do you understand how?

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: You mean that I must pretend that I am distracted with love for him.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Right--you have it.

note.#text: :  To account for the facility with which the pretended divorce appears to take place, we must remember that among the Romans either party was at liberty to dissolve the tie of marriage. Where a husband divorced his wife, the wife's "," or marriage-portion, was in general restored to her; and the same was the case where the divorce took place by mutual consent. This will account for Acroteleutium asserting that she had been divorced from Periplecomenus, and that she had retained possession of the house as having formed her marriage-portion. As a loss of affection on either side was thought to constitute a good ground for divorce, is is not to be wondered at if the Captain should believe the story that his neighbour's wife had obtained a divorce on account of her passion for himself.

p.#text: And as though by reason of that love I had fcregone my present marriage, longing for a match with him.

p.stage: pointing to the house of PERIPLECOMENUS
p.#text: Everything exactly in its due order; except only this one point; you must say that this house  was your marriage-portion; that the old man had departed hence from you after you had carried out the divorce, lest he should be afraid just now to come here into the house of another man.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: You advise me well.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: But when he comes out from in-doors, I wish you--standing at a distance there--so to make pretence, as though in comparison with his beauty you despised your own, and as though you were struck with awe at his opulent circumstances; at the same time, too, praise the comeliness of his person, the beauty of his face. Are you tutored enough?

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: I understand it all. Is it enough that I give you my work so nicely finished off that you cannot find a fault with it.

:  "." The "" here alluded to was a little cushion padded with wool, which was placed before weak or diseased eyes to absorb the moisture. It is supposed to have been either bound against the part affected, or else to have been held in the hand and applied every now and then. Commentators seem to think that here Pleusicies holds it up to his eye with his hand when addressing the Captain. They are at a loss to know why Palaestrio recommends this, as the Captain has never seen Pleusicles, who was at  when Philocomasium was carried off. Still, though it is not mentioned, it may be, because the Captain had seen Pleusicles before he went to ; or, what is more probable, that, affecting to have weak eyes, Pleusicles may not appear so comely as he really is, and not thereby excite any suspicion in the Captain's mind as to his intentions.

p.#text: I'm content. Now , in your turn, learn what charge I shall give to you So soon as this shall be done, when she shall have gone in, then do you immediately take care to come here dressed in the garb of a master of a ship. Have on a broad-brimmed hat of iron-grey, a woollen shade before your eyes; have on an iron-grey cloak (for that is the seaman's colour); have it fastened over the left shoulder, your right arm projecting out, * * * * * * your clothes some way well girded up, pretend as though you are some master of a ship. And all these requisites are at the house of this old gentleman, for he keeps fishermen.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: Well, when I'm dressed out, why don't you tell me what I'm to do then?

p.#text: Come here, and, in the name of her mother, bring word to Philocomasium, that, if she would return to , she must go with you to the harbour directly, and that she must order it to be carried down to the ship if she wishes anything to be put on board; that if she doesn't go, you must weigh anchor, for the wind is favourable.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: I like your plan much: do proceed.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: The Captain will at once advise her to go speedily that she may not delay her mother.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: Every way you are clever.

p.#text: I shall tell him that she asks for me as a helper to carry her baggage down to the harbour. I shall go, and, understand you, I shall immediately be off with you straight to .

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: And when you have reached there, I'll never let you be ashore three days before you're free.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Be off speedily and equip yourself.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: Is there anything besides?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Only to remember all this.

p.#text: I'm off.
And do you  be off hence in-doors this instant, for I'm quite sure that he'll just now be coming out hence from in-doors.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: With us your command is as good as law.

p.stage: The women go into the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.
p.#text: Come, then, begone. But see, the door opens opportunely.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What I wished I have obtained just as I wished, on kind and friendly terms, that she would leave me.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: For what reason am I to say that you have been so long in-doors?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I never was so sensible that I was beloved by that woman as now.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: How many words she did utter! How the matter was protracted! But in the end I obtained what I wanted, and I granted her what she wanted and what she asked of me. I made a present of you also to her.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What--me, too? In what way shall I exist without you?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Come, be of good heart; I'll make you free from exit, too. But I used all endeavours, if I could by any method persuade her to go away, and not take you with her, she forced me, however.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: In the Gods and yourself I'll place my trust. Yet, at the last, although it is bitter to me that I must be deprived of an excellent master, yourself, at least it is a pleasure to me that, through my means, by reason of the excellence of your beauty, this has happened to you with regard to this lady neighbour, whom I am now introducing to you.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What need of words? I'll give you liberty and wealth if you obtain her for me.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I'll win her.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: But I'm impatient.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: But moderation is requisite; curb your desires; don't be over anxious. But see, here she is herself; she is coming out of doors.

div2.stage: Enter ACROTELEUTIUM and MILPHIDIPPA from the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.

p.#text: . Mistress, see! the Captain's near.
. Where is he?

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: Only look to the left. Eye him askance, that he mayn't perceive that we are looking at him.

sp.speaker: ACROTELEUTIUM
sp.p: I see him. Troth, now's the time, in our mischief, for us to become supremely mischievous.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: 'Tis for you to begin.

p.#text: . Prithee, did you see him yourself?  Don't spare your voice, so that he may hear.
. By my troth, I talked with his own self, at my ease, as long as I pleased, at my leisure, at my own discretion, just as I wished.
. Do you hear what she says?
. I hear. How delighted she is because she had access to you.
. O happy woman that you are!

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: How I do seem to be loved!

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: You are deserving of it.

p.#text: . By my troth, 'tis passing strange what you say, that you had access to him and prevailed. They say that he is usually addressed, like a king, through letters or messengers.
. But, i' faith, 'twas with difficulty I had an opportunity of approaching and beseeching him.
. How renowned you are among the fair
. I shall submit, since Venus wills it so.

. By heavens! I return to Venus grateful thanks, and her I do beseech and entreat, that I may win him whom I love and whom I seek to win, and that to me he may prove gentle, and not make a difficulty about what I desire.
. I hope it may be so; although many ladies are seeking to win him for themselves, he disdains them and estranges himself from all but you alone.
. Therefore this fear torments me, since he is so disdainful, lest his eyes, when he beholds me, should change his sentiments, and his own gracefulness should at once disdain my form.
. He will not do so; be of good heart.
. How she does slight herself!
. I fear lest your account may have surpassed my looks.
I've taken care of this, that you shall be fairer than his expectations.

. Troth, if he shall refuse to take me as his wife, by heavens I'll embrace his knees and entreat him! If I shall be unable to prevail on him, in some way or other, I'll put myself to death. I'm quite sure that without him I cannot live.
. I see that I must prevent this woman's death. Shall I accost her?

Unless you wish to lose that glory which you have, please have a care what you do. For I know that this was never the lot of any mortal, except two persons, yourself and Phaon of , to be loved so desperately.

p.#text: . I'll go in-doors--or, my dear Milphidippa, do you call him out of doors.
. Aye; let's wait until some one comes out.
. I can't restrain myself from going il to him.
. The door's fastened. ACROT. . I'll break it in then.
. You are not in your senses.
. If he has ever loved, or if he has wisdom equal to his beauty, whatever I may do through love, he will pardon me by reason of his compassionate feelings.
. Prithee, do see, how distracted the poor thing is with love.
. 'Tis mutual in us.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Hush! Don't you let her hear.

p.#text: . Why do you stand stupefied? Why don't you knock?
. Because he is not within whom I want.

note.#text: :  In Ritschel's edition, these words are attributed to Palaestrio. This is clearly a mistake, for Palaestrio has not yet joined in their conversation. He and his master are listening to what they say.

p.#text: . How do you know?
. By my troth, I do know it easily; for my nose would scent him if he were within.
. She is a diviner. Because she is in love with me, Venus has made her prophesy.
. He is somewhere or other close at hand whom I do so long to behold. I'm sure I smell him.
. Troth, now, she really sees better with her nose than with her eyes.
. She is blind from love.
. Prithee, do support me.
. Why?
. Lest I should fall.
. Why?
. Because I cannot stand; my senses--my senses are sinking so by reason of my eyes.
. Heavens! you've seen the Captain.
. I have.
. I don't see him. Where is he?
. Troth, you would see him if you were in tove.
. I' faith, you don't love him more than I do myself, with your good leave.
. No doubt all of the women, as soon as each has seen you, are in love with you.
. I don't know whether you have heard it from me or not; I'm the grandson of Venus.
. My dear Milphidippa, prithee do approach and accost him.
. How she does stand in awe of me!
. She is coming towards us.
. I wish to speak with you.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: And we with you.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: I have brought my mistress out of the house, as you requested me.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: So I see.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: Request her, then, to approach.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Since you have entreated it, I have prevailed upon my mind not to detest her just like other women.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: I' faith she wouldn't be able to utter a word if she were to come near you; while she was looking at you, her eyes have in the meantime tied her tongue.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I see that this woman's disorder must be cured.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: See how terrified she is since she beheld you.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Even armed men are the same; don't wonder at a woman being so. But what does she wish me to do?

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: You to come to her house; she wishes to live and to pass her life with you.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What!--I come home to her, when she is a married woman? Her husband is to be stood in fear of.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: Why,--for your sake, she has turned her husband out of her house.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: How? How could she do so?

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: The house was her marriage-portion.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Was it so?

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: It was so, on my word.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Bid her go home; I'll be there just now.

sp.speaker: MILPHIDIPPA
sp.p: Take care, and don't keep her in expectation; don't torment her feelings.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Not I, indeed. Do you go then.

p.stage: ACROTELEUTIUM and MILPHIDIPPA go into the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.
p.#text: We are going.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: But what do I see?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What do you see?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: See there, some one is coming, I know not who, but in a sailor's dress.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: He is surely wanting us, now; really, it is the shipmaster.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: He's come, I suppose, to fetch her.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I fancy so.

div2.stage: Enter PLEUSICLES, at a distance, in a Sailor's dress.
