p.#text: . Did I not know that another man in other ways has done many a thing unbecomingly on account of love, I should be more ashamed by reason of love for me to be going in this garb. But since I have learned that many persons by reason of love have committed many actions, disgraceful and estranged from what is good, * * * * * for I pass by how Achilles suffered his comrades to be slain----But there's Palaestrio, he's standing with the Captain. My talk must now be changed for another kind. Woman is surely born of tardiness itself. For every other delay, which is a delay just as much, seems a less delay than that which is on account of a woman. I really think that this is done merely from habit. But I shall call for this Philocomasium. I'll knock at the door then. Hallo! is there any one here?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Young man--what is it? What do you want? Why are you knocking?

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: I'm come to inquire for Philocomasium; I'm come from her mother. If she's for going, let her set off. She is delaying us all; we wish to weigh anchor.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Her things have been some time in readiness. Hearkye, Palaestrio, take some assistants with you to carry to the ship her golden trinkets, her furniture, apparel, all her precious things. All the articles are already packed up which I gave her.

p.#text: I'll go.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: Troth now, prithee, do make haste.

note.#text: :  He asks "what has been done with" or "become of," his eye? On which Pleusicles tells him, by way of a quibble, that he has got his eye, alluding to the right one, while the Captain refers to the left, against which the "" is placed.

p.#text: There shall be no delay. Pray, what is it that has been done with your eye?
Troth, hut I have my eye.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: But the left one I mean.

note.#text: :  There is a pun here, which cannot be preserved in the translation. "" "If I kept away from the sea," may also be read, "," "If I refrained from loving." The Captain understands him in the former sense, thinking that he means that he has got a disease in his eye, which may be increased by leading a seafaring life.

p.#text: I'll tell you. On account of the sea, I use this eye less; but if I kept away from the sea, I should use the one like the other. But they are detaining me too long.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: See, here they are coming out.

div2.stage: Enter PALAESTRIO and PHILOCOMASIUM from the CAPTAIN'S house.

p.#text: . Prithee, when will you this day make an end of your weeping?

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: What can I do but weep? I am going away hence where I have spent my days most happily.

p.#text: See, there's the man that has come from your mother and sister .

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: I see him.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Palaestrio, do you hear?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: What is your pleasure?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Aren't you ordering those presents to be brought out which I gave her?

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: Health to you, Philocomasium.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: And health to you.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: Your mother and sister bade me give their love to you.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: Heaven prosper them.

note.#text: :  Thornton justly observes that this excuse for the pretended mother not making her appearance is fair enough, but there is no reason alleged why the sister should not come, except that we may suppose that she stays to nurse and comfort her sick parent.

p.#text: They beg you to set out, so that, while the wind is fair, they may set sail. But if your mother's eyes had been well, she would have come together with me.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: I'll go; although I do it with regret-duty compels me.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: You act wisely.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: If she had not been passing her life with myself, this day she would have been a blockhead.

p.#text: I am distracted at this, that I am estranged from such a man. For you are able to make any woman what-ever abound in wit; and because I was living with you, for that reason I was of a very lofty spirit. I see that I must lose that loftiness of mind.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Don't weep.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: I can't help it when I look upon you.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Be of good courage.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: I know what pain it is to me.

p.#text: I really don't wonder now, Philocomasium, if you were here with happiness to yourself, when I, a servant--as I look at him, weep because we are parting , so much have his beauty, his manners, his valour, captivated your feelings.

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: Prithee, do let me embrace you before I depart?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: By all means

p.#text: . O my eyes! O my life!

p.stage: He takes hold of her, and she pretends to faint.
p.#text: Do hold up the woman, I entreat you, lest she should fall.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What means this?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Because, after she had quitted you, she suddenly became faint, poor thing.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Run in and fetch some water.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I want no water; but I had rather you would keep at a distance. Prithee, don't you interfere till she comes to.

p.stage: observing PLEUSICLES, who is holding PHILOCOMASIUM in his arm.

note.#text: :  "" is a strong expression here; it literally means to weld iron with iron. hammering it in a red-hot state

p.#text: They have their heads too closely in contact between them; I don't like it; he is soldering his lips to hers. What the plague are you about?

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: I was trying whether she was breathing or not.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: You ought to have applied your ear then.

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: If you had rather, I'll let her go.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: No, I don't care; do you support her.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: To my misery, I'm quite distracted.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Go and bring here from in-doors all the things that I have given her.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: And even now, household God, do I salute thee before I depart; my fellow-servants, both male and female, all farewell, and happy may you live; prithee, though absent, among yourselves bestow your blessings upon me as well.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Come, Palaestrio, be of good courage.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Alas! alas! I cannot but weep since from you I must depart.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Bear it with patience.

p.#text: . Ha! how's this? What means it? Hail, O light!

sp.speaker: PLEUSICLES
sp.p: Are you recovered now?

sp.speaker: PHILOCOMASIUM
sp.p: Prithee, what person am I embracing? I'm undone. Am I myself?

p.#text: . Fear not, my delight.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What means all this?

note.#text: :  Palaestrio cannot help exclaiming against the indiscreet conduct of the lovers. The Captain overhears him, and asks him what is the matter. He adroitly turns it off, by saying, "that if thus openly ---- the goods and furniture are carried through the city, he very much fears that his, master will be censured for his extreme prodigality."

p.#text: Just now she swooned away here. * * * * * * I fear and dread that this at last may take place too openly.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What is that you say?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: I fear that some one may turn it to your discredit, while all these things are being carried after us through the city.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I have given away my own property, and not theirs. I care but little for other people. Be off then, go with the blessing of the Gods.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: 'Tis for your sake I say it.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I believe you.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: And now farewell!

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: And heartily farewell to you!

stage: to PLEUSICLES and PHILOCOMASIUM as they leave.
p.#text: Go you quickly on; I'll overtake you directly; I wish to speak a few words with my master.  Although you have ever deemed others more faithful to yourself than me, still do I owe you many thanks for all things; and if such were your feelings, I would rather be a slave to you by far than be the freedman of another.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Be of good courage.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Ah me! When it comes in my mind, how my manners must be changed, how womanish manners must be learnt, and the military ones forgotten!

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Take care and be honest.

note.#text: :  A pun is thought to be intended here on the word "," but of so wretched a nature that it is not worth any further allusion to it.

p.#text: I can be so no longer; I have lost all inclination.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Go, follow them; don't linger.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Fare you right well.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: And heartily fare you well.

note.#text: :  He hypocritically entreats his master not to desert him in need, should he be made free, and be thereby thrown entirely upon his own resources.

p.#text: Prithee, do remember me; if perchance I should happen to be made free, I'll send the news to you; don't you forsake me.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: That is not my habit.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Consider every now and then how faithful I have been to you. If you do that, then at last you'll know who is honest towards you and who dishonest.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I know it; I have often found that true, as well before as to-day in especial.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Do you know it? Aye, and this day I'll make you hereafter say still more how true it is.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I can hardly refrain from bidding you to stay.

note.#text: :  There is considerable drollery in his anxiety lest his master should suddenly change his mind and refuse to let him go. His situation would, indeed, under such circumstances have proved an unfortunate one.

p.#text: Take you care how you do that. They may say that you are a liar and not truthful, that you have no honor; they may say that no one of your slaves is trustworthy except my-self. If, indeed, I thought you could do it with honor, I should advise you. But it cannot be; take care how you do so.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Be off; I'll be content then, whatever happens.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRIO
sp.p: Then, fare you well.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: 'Twere better you should go with a good heart.

p.#text: Still, once more, farewell.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Before this affair, I had always thought that he was a most rascally servant; still, I find that he is faithful to me. When I consider with myself, I have done unwisely in parting with him. I'll go hence at once now to my love here: the door, too, I perceive, makes a noise there.

div2.stage: Enter a BOY from the house of PERIPLECOMENUS.

p.#text: . Don't you be advising me; I remember my duty; this moment I'll find him. Wherever on earth he may chance to be, I'll search him out; I'll not be sparing of my pains.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: 'Tis I he is looking for, I'll go and meet this boy.

sp.speaker: A BOY.
sp.p: O, I'm looking for you; save you, dearest sir, one loaded by opportunity with her gifts, and whom before all others two Divinities do favour.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: What two?

sp.speaker: A BOY.
sp.p: Mars and Venus.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: A sprightly boy.

sp.speaker: A BOY.
sp.p: She entreats that you will go in; she wishes--she longs for you, and while expecting you, she's dying for you. Do succour one in love. Why do you stay? Why don't you go in?

p.#text: Well, I'll go.

note.#text: :  He alludes to the attitude in which the old gentleman, Periplecomenus, is standing in-doors, ready to sally forth on the Captain the moment he is entrapped.

p.#text: There has he entangled himself at once in the toils. The snare is prepared: the old gentleman is standing at his post to attack the letcher, who is so boastful of his good looks; who thinks that, whatever woman sees him, all are in love with him; whom all, both men and women, detest. Now I will on to the uproar; I hear a tumult within.

note.#text: Thornton here remarks, that "there cannot be a stranger proof of the absurdities into which the ancients were forced by a preservation of the unity of place than the present passage. The Captain is surprised in Periplecomenus's own house, carrying on an intrigue with the old gentleman's pretended wife, in consequence of which they proceed to frighten him with the cook's threatening to go to work upon him with his knife. Can anything be more unnatural or improbable than that for this purpose they should drag him out of the house and into the public street!

stage.#text: Enter PERIPLECOMENUS from his house, with CARIO and other SERVANTS, dragging PYRGOPOLINICES.

note.#text: :  He means, "take him in your arms," or "hoist him on your shoulders."

p.#text: Bring that fellow along. If he doesn't follow, drag him, lifted on high, out of doors. Make him to be between heaven and earth; cut him in pieces.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: By my troth, I do entreat you, Periplecomenus.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: By my troth, you do entreat in vain. Take care, Cario, that that knife of yours is very sharp.

sp.speaker: CARIO
sp.p: Why, it's already longing to rip up the stomach of this letcher. I'll make his entrails hang just as a bauble hangs from a baby's neck.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I'm a dead man.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Not yet; you say so too soon.

sp.speaker: CARIO
sp.p: Shall I have at this fellow now?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Aye,--but first let him be thrashed with cudgels.

sp.speaker: CARIO
sp.p: True, right lustily.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Why have you dared, you disgraceful fellow, to seduce another man's wife?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: So may the Gods bless me, she came to me of her own accord.

p.#text: It's a lie. Lay on.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Stay, while I tell----

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Why are you hesitating?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Will you not let me speak?

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Speak, then.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I was entreated to come here.

p.#text: How did you dare? There's for you, take that.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: O! O! I've had enough. Prithee, now.

sp.speaker: CARIO
sp.p: Am I to begin cutting him up at once?

note.#text: :  "." He means, "stretch him out as you would spread out to their utmost length the wings of a bird."

p.#text: As soon as you like. Stretch the fellow out, and spread out his pinions in opposite ways.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: By heavens, prithee, do hear my words before he cuts me.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Speak before you're made of no sex.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I supposed that she was a widow; and so her maid, who was her go-between, informed me.

note.#text: :  This is an allusion to the Captains own boast in Act IV. s. 4, that he was the grandson of Venus.

p.#text: Now take an oath that you won't injure any person for this affair, because you have been beaten here today, or shall be beaten hereafter, if we let you go safe hence, you dear little grandson of Venus.

note.#text: :  Dione, according to Homer, was the name of the mother of Venus; but the name is much more frequently used, as in the present instance, to signify Venus herself. He appropriately swears by these guardian Deities of intrigue. The translation of l. 1416 is somewhat modified.

p.#text: I swear by Dione and Mars that I will hurt no one because I have been beaten here this day; and I think that it was rightfully done; and if I don't go hence further injured, I am rightly punished for the offence.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: But what if you don't do so?

note.#text: :  "." A gross pun is here intended, and in l. 1420 as well. The word here signifies "forsworn," or "perjured," so infamous, that his testimony will never be received in a Court of justice.

p.#text: Then, may I always have my word not to be trusted

sp.speaker: CARIO
sp.p: Let him be beaten once more; after that I think he may be dismissed.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: May the Gods ever bless you, since you so kindly come as my advocate.

note.#text: :  The golden "" was worth ten silver ones, or one thousand "," of about ninepence three-farthings each.

p.#text: Give us a golden mina, then.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: For what reason?

sp.speaker: CARIO
sp.p: That we may now let you go hence unmaimed, you little grandson of Venus; otherwise you shall not escape from here; don't you deceive yourself.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: It shall be given you.

note.#text: :  The "" was an outer garment worn among the Greeks and  nations, somewhat resembling our scarfs. That worn by the Captain would probably be of great value, which of course would tempt the cupidity of his persecutors. The translation of l. 1426 is somewhat modified.

p.#text: You're very wise. As for your tunic, and your scarf, and sword, don't at all hope for them; you shan't have them.

sp.speaker: A SERVANT.
sp.p: Shall I beat him again, or do you let him go?

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I'm tamed by your cudgels. I do entreat you.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: Loose him.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: I return you thanks.

sp.speaker: PERIPLECOMENUS
sp.p: If I ever catch you here again, I'll insert a disqualifying clause.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Well: I make no objection.

stage: PERIPLECOMENUS, CARIO, and SERVANTS go into his house.
Enter SCLEDRUS and other SERVANTS of the CAPTAIN.
p.#text: Let's go in, Cario.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Here are some of my servants, I see. Tell me, is Philocomasium off yet.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: Aye, some time since.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Ah me!

note.#text: :  Sceledrus, probably, only enters at this moment with the other servants of the Captain; the editions, in general, somewhat absurdly represent him as present from the beginning of the Fifth Act.

p.#text: You would say that still more if you were to know what I know, for that fellow who had the wool before his eye was no sailor.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Who was he, then?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: A lover of Philocomasium's.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: How do you know?

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I do know: for after they had got out of the city gate, they didn't wait a moment before falling to kissing and embracing each other at once.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: O wretched fool that I am! I see that I have been gulled. That scoundrel of a fellow, Palaestrio, it was he that contrived this plot against me.

sp.speaker: SCELEDRUS
sp.p: I think it was properly done. If it were so done to other letchers, there would be fewer letchers here; they would stand more in awe, and give their attention less to these pursuits.

sp.speaker: PYRGOPOLINICES
sp.p: Let's go into my house.

p.#text: . Give us your applause.
